business.start.para: Mr. SPEAKER (Hon. 6. J. Bell)took the chair at 3 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: - Can the Prime Minister say whether there is any foundation for the rumour in the lobbies that the Government intends to adjourn Parliament at the end of this week with a view to holding the general elections at the end of August?
- I can only answer that the possibilities of an election have not been entirely absent from the mind of the Government.

- In view of the developments overseas, will the Minister for External Affairs allay the fear that Australia is not exercising sufficient influence in the formation of Empire foreign policy, particularly in matters relating to the Far East, by giving an assurance that Australia is not merely following blindly the decisions made at Downing-street ?

- Happily, I am able to give to the honorable member, and to the House, the most explicit assurance not only that Australia is constantly and intimately in consultation with the United Kingdom Government and the governments of the other Dominions which are concerned, but also that there is ample and recurring evidence that Australia's opinions weigh heavily and effect decisions made.

- Has the Minister for the Army been informed that the call-up of the various age groups of compulsory military trainees covers large numbers of pupils at aeronautical engineering schools, and will interfere with their studies, which are primarily designed to fit them for defence activities? Will the Minister take such action as will ensure that these students shall be exempted from the obligation to render compulsory military service?

- If the individual* referred to are engaged in reserved occupations, they will automatically be exempted from the compulsory provisions of the Defence Act. If not, and there are special circumstances surrounding their training, which would warrant their exemption, I guarantee to investigate their cases with a view to having these men released from the obligation to render military service.
- Can the Minister for Commerce make a statement to the House regarding the stage which has been reached in connexion with the proposal to build ships at Hobart?

speech.para: Air. ARCHIE CAMERON. - Certain interviews have taken place between the people at Hobart who are interested in that aspect of the industry and the Engineer Rear Admiral of the Navy Department. At the moment we are awaiting replies from the people at Hobart as to the next move to be taken.

talk.start.para: - In view of the position in the Far East, can the Minister for the Army say what steps have been taken by the Government to protect from aerial attack the petrol tanks in various parts of Australia which are so openly situated as to invite attack by an enemy?

- A considered reply to the honorable member's question would take a great deal more time than I should be allowed, but, replying broadly to it, I can say that ample steps are being taken by the Government .to deal with the possibility which the honorable gentleman somewhat pessimistically envisaged.

- Is the Minister for Supply and Development still of the same opinion as when he compiled a report, following his visit to England and the Continent, of Europe, regarding the extraction of oil from coal, in which he said that it was as much a commercial proposition as was the manufacture of guns and munitions ? If so, will he give to the company operating at Baerami, or any other company which is prepared to extract oil from coal or shale, assistance similar to that which was given to the company operating at Newnes?
- The honorable member's question relates to a matter of Government policy, and it is not usual to announce the Government's policy in response to questions without notice.

- I understand that men on the reserve list for service 'with the Royal Australian Air Force have already been provided with badges. Can the Minister for the Navy say whether badges will also be provided for men who are on the waiting list for service with the Navy?
- The matter referred to by the honorable member is receiving attention.

- Has the Minister for Supply and Development, or his department, yet had time to canvass the possibilities of employing partially crippled persons as process workers in munition establishments and other engineering works?

- The section of the factories to which the honorable gentleman's question refers is no longer under the control of the Department of Supply and Development, but I can inform the honorable member that, during the period of my control of that activity, I consulted freely with those v ho were responsible for the engaging of staff as to the possibility of finding some place in our industrial economy for partially crippled people.

speech.para: WHEAT ADVANCE. Mr. ARCHIE CAMERON. - I arn now able to inform the honorable member for Lang (Mr. Mulcahy) that the rate of interest on advances made from the No. 2 Wheat Pool which formerly was 3^- per cent, was reduced to 3^ per cent, as from the 1st July, 1940.

talk.start.para: - On the 21st June last I questioned the Minister for Supply and Development concerning a statement by Mr. Storey, Assistant Director of Aircraft Construction at Chullora, to the effect that 33 per cent, of the parts were missing from bombers that were being brought to Australia for assembling. The honorable gentleman promised u» make an inquiry into the subject and inform me of the result. Has he made that inquiry, and can he tell me whether the statement is true or otherwise?

- As I indicated a moment ago, the manufacture of munitions, which includes aircraft construction, is no longer under the control of the Department of Supply and Development. I understand that in a report which was published only this week by Mr. Essington Lewis, the DirectorGeneral of Munitions, reference was made to the subject referred to by the honorable member.

- In view of the very serious statements made by Mr. Storey regarding the shortage of parts for bombers imported into Australia, does the Minister for Supply and Development consider that he has carried out the promise given on the 21st June last by saying that the responsibility now rests on Mr. Essington Lewis? If so, will the Minister suggest how it is possible for information to be secured in this House from Mr. Essington Lewi?, who is not a member of this Parliament*
- I shall refer the honorable member's question to the Minister for Munitions in order that a reply may be furnished.
- Will the Minister for Commerce inform me how mud. longer it will take him to make a reply to representations submitted to him ou hp 23rd July last by the Melbourne Wool Merchants Association?
- I have no doubt that both the honorable member and myself have considerable regard for the cardinal virtue of patience. I shall do my best in the matter.

- I ask the Prime Minister whether his attention has been drawn to an apparently authentic announcement in the Sydney Daily Tehgraph to the effect that the Chief Justice of Australia, Sir John Latham, intends to leave the High Court Bench in order to become Australian Ambassador to Japan? "Will the Prime Minister confirm or deny that statement?
- The reply to the first part of the honorable gentleman's question is " Yes ", and to the second part of it, " No ".

- I ask the Minister for Commerce whether it is correctly rumoured that the Government has made arrangements to afford interim relief in the form of recoverable loans to employers in New Guinea and Papua, other than companies, engaged in planting who notify in writing that they are unable to meet their obligations? Is it proposed, under this form of relief, that the Administration shall advance money to pay the current wages of native labourers and also to pay off time-expired labourers, and to pay the cost of their sustenance pending repatriation and also of their repatriation? Is it proposed that licences essential to the operation of plantations shall be issued without payment in cash of the essential fees, and that the fees shall be debited to the persons concerned? .Is it also proposed that advances shall be made to cover premiums on securities which are obtained in respect of licences issued under the explosives ordinance?

- That matter is under the control of the Minister in Charge of External Territories (Mr. Nock), who is not present at to-day's sittings. I assure the honorable member that the whole matter is receiving the attention of the Government. The difficulties have been brought about by the unfortunate position of the copra industry in Papua and New Guinea as the result of the happenings of the last few months.

subdebateinfo.title: LABOUR DAY HOLIDAY IN NEW SOUTH WALES

talk.start.para: - In view of a statement that has been attributed to the. Chief Secretary of the Government of New South Wales that the granting of the Eight Hours Day holiday in New South Wales this year is dependent upon the attitude adopted by lie Commonwealth Government, I ask the Prime Minister whether this matter is subject to control by the Commonwealth Government or the State authorities?
- It is a matter which falls within the jurisdiction of the State Government.

speech.para: ADMINISTRATION OE TRANSPORT WORKERS ACT IN QUEENSLAND. Mr. GEORGE LAWSON. - As I understand that although the members of the waterside workers' organization were anxious to interview the AttorneyGeneral by deputation during his recent visit to Brisbane, but were not able to do so, I ask the right honorable gentleman whether the Government has finally considered the report of the honorable member for Macquarie (Mr. John Lawson) upon the working conditions of waterside workers? If so, does the Government intend to suspend the application of the Transport Workers Act to ports at Brisbane and elsewhere in Queensland as was recommended in that report?

talk.start.para: - The honorable gentleman is in error in supposing that I did not see the representative of the waterside workers while I was in Brisbane. I saw representatives of the employers and also the secretary of the union. The suspension of the operations of the Transport Workers Act, is, as I have said on other occasions, receiving consideration by the Government, but no decision has yet been reached in relation to the ports of Queensland.
- Is the Prime Minister able to inform honorable members on which days Parliament is likely to meet for the remainder of this week, and during next week?
- It is proposed that the House shall meet to-morrow morning but not on Friday of this week, and I have in mind that it will meet on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of next week.
- Why not come back on Tuesday?
- I shall be here on Tuesday. Will the honorable member for Denison (Mr. Mahoney) be staying here over the week-end?
- I have got to stop here. I cannot go home.
- No doubt we all shall miss the honorable member after the next election.
- I rise to order. I resent the remark of the Prime Minister that I shall not be missed after the next election.
- I said that the honorable member would be missed.
- Why does not the Prime Minister play the game?

para.inline: Mr. SPEAKER (Hon. G. J. Bell 1 Order ! The honorable member for Denison must resume his seat.

talk.start.para: - I regret it if I have said anything offensive to the honorable member. Had I said that he would not be missed, that would be offensive. What I said was that he would be missed.

debate.para: That the House, at its rising, adjourn until 10.30 a.m. to-morrow.

talk.start.para: . - The object of the motion is, of course, to provide that Parliament shall meet to-morrow morning but not meet on Friday, and the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) has intimated that he expects that the first meeting of the House next week will be on Wednesday. I wish to make clear the position of the Opposition. We are in entire agreement that the Government should be given the utmost facility to conduct its business. If it needs the week-end to prepare business for submission to Parliament, it is; perfectly fair and proper that parliamentary arrangements shall be such as will convenience it. But there must be some definiteness about this business. I take it that when the Prime Minister says that he has in mind that the House shall meet on Wednesday of next week, he intends that the House shall meet on that day.
- -What is the apprehension of the honorable Leader of the Opposition ?

- There is no apprehension. There is, however, an obligation on the members of this Parliament who have been called together in pursuance of their own resolution on a given date to deal with matters that appear on the notice-paper. I have in mind, in particular, a bill which is an essential part of the Government's financial policy for the conduct of the war. This particular bill was referred to in the budget, but the proposal has not yet been passed into law. The right honorable gentlemen will perhaps recollect that on the day when the House decided to adjourn until yesterday's date, I asked the Treasurer (Mr. Spender) whether the failure of the Government to put this bill through the Parliament before the adjournment would affect the amount of revenue which he expected to be collected in this financial year pursuant to its provisions. The honorable gentleman said that it would not affect the amount of revenue which he anticipated collecting by that tax. He said that representations had been made that the incidence of the tax should be reconsidered and that for that reason the matter was being held over until the next period of the session. The bill should be dealt with before this Parliament re-arranges its sittings in such a way as to permit the termination of the Parliament without the bill being passed. That is what I have in mind. The other taxes affecting individuals, either directly or indirectly, which were outlined in the budget, have been considered by the Parliament; but the company tax has not yet been completely dealt with. I think it is fair to say that the general support for the financial programme which the Treasurer outlined in the Budget was related to the fact that the company tax was an essential part of the whole programme. I think it was implicit in the statement of the Treasurer that that tax would be made law. I submit that it is fair and proper that the taxation proposed to be levied in order to finance the war, as introduced by the Treasurer, and as approved by the Parliament, should be completely carried insofar as its mechanics are concerned.
- We shall be ready to proceed with the bill immediately after dinner to-day.

- I take it that we shall also be given an opportunity to review the very important statement of the Minister for Commerce (Mr. Archie Cameron) last night, and also to complete the consideration of the important statement made by the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. McEwen). I am not humbugging myself; I merely wish to know whether it is intended to deal with the matters on the notice-paper and, whether I may go on making my own arrangements as Leader of the Opposition in the knowledge that this Parliament will assemble on Wednesday next? If the right honorable gentleman is agreeable to that I am quite content.
- Is the honorable member suggesting that we should meet on Tuesday? I am prepared to consider that.

- My answer to that is that I am quite agreeable to the Parliament meeting regularly and on such days during each week as are found by the Government to bemost convenient in order to enable it to submit its measures for the consideration of the Parliament. I have no finicky objection to Wednesday which would disappear if Tuesday were suggested. That is a matter on which I offer no criticism at all. I merely say that if the right honorable gentleman says that Parliament will meet on Wednesday, I take it that he means Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of next week, and, in any event, he means not so much absolute adherence to the notice-paper as the assurance that Parliament will deal with the company tax which is on the notice-paper, that the Parliament will be given an opportunity to complete its consideration of the statement made by the Minister for External Affairs and also reasonable opportunity to deal with the tremendously important statement which the Minister for Commerce was given leave to make last night. The debate on international affairs was interrupted last night in order that the Minister for Commerce might be given leave to make his statement and to have copies of it circulated to honorable members, so that they would be able to consider it fully before the resumption of the debate. I ask for an assurance that these arrangements will stand.

talker.role: Leader of the Australian Labour party - nonCommunist
talker.name: BEASLEY, John
Mr BEASLEY

talk.start.para: . - The main consideration is not so much on what days the Parliament shall meet next week as on what days it will meet in succeeding weeks, and for what length of time Parliament will be kept in session. If the Government could make up its mind in regard to this matter, it would be very helpful. There is some advantage in being able to look into the future and having some idea as to what is to happen.
- The sooner we have an election, the better for every body.

- Quite right. I agree that it might be difficult to make a decision between now and next Wednesday on the big question of the date of the elections, but I should like an indication from the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) as to what is intended in respect of the succeeding weeks of the session. Is it proposed to meet Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in one week and Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of the following week? The Prime Minister might well indicate the length of time remaining to us to complete what the Government regards as its important business. If the right honorable gentleman will do that, I shall be obliged, for we can then pretty well guess for ourselves what the future holds for us.
- Nothing would give me greater pleasure than to oblige the Honorable member.

.- While I associate myself with the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Curtin) in regard to meeting the convenience of the Government, it is rather amazing that the Government should find it necessary to have what we call a long week-end after the Parliament has been sitting for only three days. I have complained about the arrangements for sitting days and of the lack of consideration for honorable members from distant States ever since I have been a member of this House. I regret to say that the present Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) has done no better than his predecessor in that regard. I fully realize that we are passing through difficult times, and that fact must influence the decisions of the Government, but Ministers should not be altogether unmindful of the convenience of . honorable members. As a representative of a distant State, I, hi common with other honorable members, find difficulty in getting back to my home or making any arrangements for week-ends unless the Government arranges the sitting days with this in view. The Prime Minister should give some indication of what is intended so that private members can make their arrangements accordingly. Perhaps the right honorable gentleman will be good enough to say if it is proposed to sit on three days or four days a week during the present session, so that honorable members representing the more distant States may make arrangements to visit their homes and interview their constituents.

.- I was disappointed to hear the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies). We have been brought here from distant parts of the Commonwealth to attend to urgent business associated with the prosecution of Australia's war effort. Now we are told that the House will rise to-morrow and meet on only Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of next week. Having regard to the crisis with which Australia is confronted, the Government is doing its best to bring Parliament into ridicule. If there is important business to be done, Parliament should sit every week from Tuesday to Friday if necessary. If there is anything that will tend to discredit and defeat democracy it is the employment of these " Fifth-Column " tactics by the Government, which is playing up to the electors, pretending that it wants nothing so much as to get on with the nation's war effort, which the Labour party is preventing. This afternoon I asked the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) a civil question, and am not disposed to accept his insulting remarks in reply. While honorable members from distant States are compelled to remain in Canberra, members of the Government are conducting their election campaign " under the lap ". We know that the Nationalist party organizations throughout Australia are using the national broadcasting service for party purposes, saying that they do not want an election, but that it is being forced on the country by the Labour party. I challenge any one to say that I have ever done anything to hinder the Government in the sincere prosecution of our war effort, but I object to Parliament being made a laughing stock by meeting on only two or three days in the week, and then adjourning for a long week-end. Members of the Government can go to their electorates, but members representing Tasmanian constituencies must remain here. I maintain that I am just as much entitled to return to my home, and to my wife and children, as is the Prime Minister to return to his. If the Prime Minister intends that an election shall be held, he should say so. If it is intended that Parliament shall sit beyond next week, let us have regular sittings on four days a week if necessary, and let the Government not continue to give the impression that it is anxious to set up a totalitarian State in Australia. That certainly seems to be what the Prime Minister is aiming at. I am opposed to that tendency, just as I object to his sneering remark that I would not be missed from public life. I can say without hesitation that my record in public life is as clean as that of the Prime Minister.

.- -I have never known a government which, in the matter of the meeting of Parliament, pursues a course of such unpredictable irregularity as this Government does. I have complained of it before. We never know what the sitting days of Parliament are to be, and we are precluded by that fact from making any arrangements ahead for any length of time. That is a source of irritation and discomfort to every body concerned. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Curtin) is satisfied to give the Government what time it requires in the week-end for the preparation of its programme, and I am offering no special objection to the adjournment to-morrow night. I point out, however, that members come to this Parliament from very distant parts of the Commonwealth, and that the assembling of this Parliament is no light matter, having regard to the distances which must be covered. If we adjourn tomorrow, we shall be practically wasting Friday of this week, whereas, if Parliament were to meet on Friday as usual, honorable members could, even on a motion for the adjournment of the House, impart much useful information to the Government and to the country about matters which they have too few opportunities to discuss. This could be done without mating any demands on the attention or energies of members of the Government. My protest has greater significance if, as we are led to believe, the Government is not candid with us, but is merely sparring for time while it makes its own arrangements for an election campaign about which it does not take the House into its confidence. Having registered my protest, I leave the matter there for the moment.

.- For my part, I am not much concerned as to whether the Government adjourns Parliament for a long week-end or a short one. As a matter of fact, I would not object to being here in perpetuity. However, I think that the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) should inform us as to what time this week or next week he intends to see His Excellency the Governor-General for the purpose of tendering advice which will have the effect of giving the Government an opportunity to scrape the Country party barnacles off the ship of state.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: - I ask the Minister for the Army whether arrangements have been made for the evacuation and provisioning of the civil population of coastal towns in the event of -an invasion of Australia ?
- If the honorable member is referring to his own State of Tasmania, I suggest that the information he seeks may be made available to him toy the Premier of that State.

- I ask the Minister for the Army whether the Government intends to issue regulations for the prevention of the sale of military, naval and airforce uniforms to unauthorized persons? Can the honorable gentleman explain why this action has not so far been taken, particularly in the light of the number of public statements that have been made in regard to the matter?

- It is the intention of the Government to issue regulations designed to prevent the sale of service uniforms to unauthorized persons. Those regulations, I understand, are at present in draft, and should shortly be approved and published.

- I have received from recruiting committees on the north coast of New South Wales, notably at Murwillumbah and Lismore, the complaint that men who enlisted for the Australian Imperial Force as far back as the 25th May have not yet been called up, and that these committees have received from the recruiting depot at Newcastle the notification that, for the present, no further call-up is to be made. The circumstances of these men preclude their acceptance of positions in civil life, and their minds are in an unsettled state. Will the Minister for the Army state what is projected in respect of them?
- If the circumstances are as the honorable member has stated them to be, I regret the fact, and shall take steps to correct them.

- In view of the extremely serious financial position of the majority of the wheat-growers of Australia, due to low and fluctuating prices and to other serious circumstances caused by the war, will the Prime Minister state whether the Government has in view arrangements for the preservation and continued operation of the wheat industry, and avoidance of the dispossession of the growers of their farms and implements ?
- The whole of that very important matter is under the constant consideration of my colleague, the Minister for Commerce.

subdebateinfo.title: MAIL FOR THE AUSTRALIAN IMPERIAL FORCE

talk.start.para: - Yesterday the honorable members for Griffith and Moreton asked questions concerning the despatch of mails to members of the Australian Imperial Force on service abroad. I now inform those honorable members that direct mails are despatched by the Postal Department to the different vessels of the Royal Australian Navy, to Army Base Post Offices in Palestine and England, and to any units of the Royal Australian Air Force abroad by every available vessel. T.he mails are made up and labelled in accordance with secret instructions issued by the Service Departments concerned. In addition, mail matter for certain units of the Australian Imperial Force which are abroad is forwarded by the Postal Department to an Army post office in Melbourne, where the correspondence is checked with special records in order to ensure that it is correctly routed to Palestine or England, as the case may be, and is then returned to the Postal Department for despatch overseas.

speech.para: At the request of the Service Departments concerned, mail matter for members of the Commonwealth Forces abroad is to be addressed as follows : -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Navy. - The addressee's rank or rating and name, together with the name of the ship to which he is attached, followed by the words "Care General Post Office ".

item.label: (b)
item.para: Army. - The addressee's number, rank and name, together with the unit to to which he is attached, followed by the words " Australian Imperial Force abroad ".

item.label: (c)
item.para: Air Force. - In the case of individual units, the addressee's number, rank, initials and name, together with the unit to which he is attached, followed by the words " Royal Australian Air Force abroad ". In the case of trainees sent to Canada under the Empire air training scheme, the addressee's number, rank and name, followed by the words " Care Royal Canadian Air Force, Ottawa, Canada ".

speech.para: Since the departure from Australia of the Australian Imperial Force, soldiers' mail has been despatched on ten occasions to Palestine and on five occasions to England. Certain mails despatched to Palestine contained mails for the troops who were diverted to England, and the Department of the Army has made all the necessary arrangements for such mail matter to be re-despatched from Palestine to England without delay.

The Empire air mail service is regularly utilized for the conveyance of mail matter to the Australian Imperial Force which is fully prepaid for aerial transmission at ls. 6d. a half oz. The air service operates to a weekly frequency in each direction between Australia and Durban, via Egypt. Mails for the United Kingdom are conveyed by the first available transport. The frequency of the Empire air mail service will be increased to twice a week on the 24th August next.

Information concerning the extent of the censorship imposed on mail matter to and from the Defence Forces is not available to my department, but it is understood that such mail matter is afforded priority of treatment and that no delay occurs in the transmission of harmless correspondence on account of censorship requirements.

The postal service provided within the Australian Imperial Force abroad is conducted by the Army Postal Service. The facilities comprise the delivery and despatch of mail matter. Information concerning the detailed arrangements in operation in Palestine and England is not available to my department at present.

It is understood that at least two mails - those despatched in June - have now been delivered to the Australian Imperial Force in England. The statement mentioned in the press of the 5th August refers to the loss of mails for Palestine and the Middle East, which closed in Melbourne about the 20th May.

talk.start.para: - Did I understand the Postmaster-General to say that all mails for members of the Australian Imperial Force abroad are first sent to Melbourne to be checked by the military authorities, and are then returned to the different States for despatch ?
- Not all mails; only certain mails.

- Have representations been, made to the Department of Supply and Development regarding an increase of the output of power alcohol at Sarina? If so, to what extent is it proposed that the plant shall be increased?

- As the result of consultations between the distillery company at Sarina and myself some time ago, steps were taken by the company to increase its capacity to produce power alcohol, but difficulty has been experienced in obtaining increased supplies of molasses. It may interest the honorable member to learn that the Government has recently decided to establish a special committee, under the presidency of the Assistant Minister for Supply (Mr. Fadden), to discuss ways and means of increasing the production of power alcohol, not only from molasses and other by-products of sugar, but also from other local products.
- Can the AttorneyGeneral say when it is intended to proceed with the Trade Marks Bill and the Patents Bill now on the notice-paper?

- The honorable member will recall that, following a consultation with the leaders of the various political parties in this House, it was decided to refer the bill to a committee. I cannot say whether the bill will be proceeded with in the near future, because there are forces at work which may disturb the best schemes of men.

- Can the AttorneyGeneral say whether there is a prospect of legislation being introduced in the immediate future to safeguard the interests of members of the Australian Imperial Force in respect of claims for rent and interest on mortgages?

- The question of a moratorium for members of the Australian Imperial Force is under consideration. As the honorable member will readily agree, the matter is not without its difficulties. However, it is hoped that in the near future a regulation will be promulgated in this connexion.

- If it be necessary, as was stated . yesterday, for single men serving in military camps situated outside their electorates to transfer, after three months, their electoral enrolment to another division, will the Prime Minister take action to enable them to retain their enrolment for the divisions in which they normally reside?
- The matter is engaging the attention of the Government.
- Can the Minister for Supply and Development inform the House when the munitions establishment at Geelong, which was completed many months ago, will be brought into production?
- I shall ascertain the facts and let the honorable member have an answer to-morrow.

- 'Can the Minister for the Army say whether it is a fact that certain voluntary women war workers, who were engaged upon censorship work in Sydney, divulged the contents of letters passing between members of the Navy and their relatives and friends ashore? If so, what action does the Minister propose to take?

- In any cases which are brought under my notice, or the notice of the censorship authorities, of individuals on the censorship staff breaking their oath of secrecy such persons will .be immediately dismissed. If the honorable gentleman will give to me any specific instances in which such oath has been broken and no action taken, I shall cause an investigation to be made.

- Can the Minister for the Navy say whether it is a fact that, as the result of inquiries made following an interview which I had with him recently, it was found that the complaints were justified and that he communicated with the Minister for the Army with a view to appropriate action being taken? Can he say whether he has yet been advised what action the Minister for the Army proposes to take, and if action has not already been taken, what he himself proposes to do in the matter?

- The complaints lodged by the honorable member, and others, in this connexion were proved to my satisfaction to be well founded. I have every reason to believe that the Minister for the Army dealt with the matter in a satisfactory way.
- In order to prevent confusion among the electors, will the Prime Minister see that new rolls are printed before the next elections take place?
- I shall do my best in the matter,

- Will the Minister representing the Minister for the Interior endeavour to get the assistance of the police authorities in the States in which separate electoral rolls are used, in order to obtain as complete rolls as possible for the forthcoming federal elections? There was a time when this course was followed, but recently it was discontinued.
- I shall have pleasure in conveying the honorable member's suggestion to my colleague, the Minister for the Interior.
- Some time ago a deputation waited on the Minister for Commerce asking for the restoration of the fertilizers subsidy. Is the Minister yet in a position to make a statement on the subject?
- Not at present.

- Has the Minister for the Army noticed in the press a statement by the secretary of the Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales that the society hopes, if the Army will co-operate with it, that the Sydney Show will be held next Easter? Has he also seen the statement that the loss to Sydney traders if no show be held will be between £1,500,000 and £2,000,000? Has the Minister any statement to make in regard to this matter?
- As I have not yet seen either of the statements referred to, I am not in a position to comment on them, but I shall read them in order to inform my mind on the subject.

- Is the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Customs in a position to comply with the request which I made during the earlier period of the session that he should make available to honorable members the Townsend report on shipbuilding in Australia ?
- I shall consult with my colleague, the Minister for Trade and Customs, and see what can be done.

- Has the PostmasterGeneral yet made representations to the Treasurer regarding the issue of wireless listeners' licences free to invalid and oldage pensioners, as was requested by a recent deputation?
- Following the representations that were made to me, the matter was inquired into. A statement in reply to the deputation is now ready.

- Is the Minister for the Army able to indicate the attitude of the Government towards the numerous requests from country centres for the establishment of what may be termed primary military camps, so that recruits may receive their initial training locally?

- The Department of the Army establishes camps in various country centres where railways, light and water, and other facilities are available. and considerable numbers of men can be housed satisfactorily. Obviously, it is impossible to establish camps in numerous country centres because of the heavy expenditure which would be involved and the difficulty of providing equipment and instructors.

- Is the Minister for Defence Co-ordination aware of the serious position that has arisen because work on defence undertakings has been suspended through lack of funds? I refer particularly to defence works in one of the most important industrial centres of Australia. If so, will he take immediate action to ensure that further sums of money shall be made available, thereby enabling men who have been put off to be re-employed?
- I am certainly not aware that any essential defence works have been suspended for lack of funds. I assure the honorable member that that is not the case.

- Is it a fact that men engaged on home defence are receiving lower rates of pay for the same class of work than are paid to men' who have volunteered for active service but are still in Australia? If so, will the Minister for the Army take steps to see that all men doing similar work are paid at the same rates?

- The allegation contained in the honorable member's question has no basis in fact. The same rates are paid for similar work up to the time of embarkation. After embarkation, deferred pay is credited to men of the Australian Imperial Force.

- Has the attention of the Minister for Defence Coordination been drawn to the fact that a large proportion of men who have enlisted in the Australian Imperial Force have not been supplied with some details of their equipment? Some me:n who have been in camp for about a month are still without hats. Is this due to the excessive efficiency of the recruiting authorities or to the lack of efficiency of the Department of Supply and Development ?

- I am informed by the Minister concerned that there is no foundation for the statements that have been made to the effect that a substantial number of men in the Australian Imperial Force are without some part of their equipment. It may be that ou some rare occasion an individual is minus an item of his equipment, but . such instances are inevitable. Speaking broadly, there is no truth in the charge.
- I ask the Minister whether, in order to test the truth of _the prompting he received from the Minister for Supply and Development, to the effect that there was no shortage-
- The honorable member is not in order.
- How are we to get satisfaction on this matter?
-The honorable member was not in order in asking that something be done in order to test the truth of a Minister's statement.

- I ask the Minister for Defence Co-ordination whether he will call for a report from the authorities at the Ingleburn and Tamworth camps, as to whether there is any shortage of equipment among the troops, so that we may be informed as to the truth regarding the position?
- I ask the Minister not to reply to that question.

- Will the Minister for Defence Co-ordination call for a report from the authorities at the Ingleburn and Tamworth camps to discover whether the soldiers in those camps are without any of their equipment?
- I have actually anticipated the honorable member's question, and have asked my colleague the Minister for the Army to obtain a report on the subject.
- As surveys show that there will probably be a demand - for wheat when the war is over, I ask the

speech.para: Minister for Commerce whether the officers of his department have made an investigation, or whether they contemplate doing so, with the object of providing storage on farms or at the seaboard for our surplus wheat, so that thu demand which may arise for it may be met, and so that continuity of operations in this industry may be possible in the interim.

talk.start.para: - The Department of Commerce has given consideration to this subject, but we always come up against the insuperable obstacle that no one knows when the war will end,
- As it is quite obvious that the Prime Minister is not aware of the deplorable ineffectiveness of our defence measures-
- Order !

- I ask the Prime Minister whether, in view of the knowledge which many honorable members on this side of the House possess, concerning our unpreparedness to defend Australia, he will endeavour to arrange a meeting of all the parties in the House to discuss the whole subject, as honorable members do not desire to discuss it publicly, for that might create something of a panic. We desire a secret session of the Parliament to be held at which the whole situation may be openly discussed. Is the Prime Minister prepared to summon a secret session of Parliament, in order that honorable members may be informed of the true position and may not be tempted to divulge facts which have come under their notice, with the idea that to do so would be to render a service to th, country ?
- I anticipate saying something about that subject to-morrow.

- Before the Prime Minister gives favorable consideration to the request for a secret session of Parliament, I ask him whether he will read the report that appears in a section of to-day's press respecting a secret meeting of the Country party that was held last night - a report that consists almost wholly of untruths?
- I shall consider the honorable member's suggestion. My experience of secret arrangements is that " there is nothing hid that shall not be known ".

- Will the Minister for the Army inform me whether it is a fact that not one Tasmanian who joined the postal unit was given a commission? Is it a fact that Tasmanians who had high qualifications and were capable of holding commissions were not wanted ? If so, why?

- If the honorable gentleman will give me particular cases I shall be prepared to consider them. It is difficult to reply to generalities. I assure the honorable member that, contrary to his repeatedly expressed opinion, Tasmanians have not suffered any in* justice in respect of appointments.

- I ask the Prime Minister whether, in view of the fact that the basic wage was recently increased in consequence of the higher cost of living, he will consider a request by invalid, old-age and war pensioners that their allowances be increased?
- I shall bring the matter under the notice of my colleagues.

- In view of the fact that petitions bearing many thousands of signatures have been presented to this Parliament by honorable members of all parties, except the Country party, for an increase of the rate of invalid and oldage pensions to 303. a week, I ask the Treasurer whether the Government proposes to take notice of the submissions that have been made? Will he indicate whether it is proposed to increase the pension rate in consequence of the increase of the cost of living?
- The question deals with a matter of policy.

- I ask the Minister for Supply and Development whether he was responsible for a report which appeared in the press to the effect that the best guarantee he could give that petrol rationing would not be brought into effect was that he had bought a new car? Seeing that, following his example, a great many other people bought new cars about the same time, does the Government propose to provide any compensation for them?

- The implication in the honorable member's question is as incorrect as the implication in an earlier question which he directed to the Minister for the Army concerning supplies. However, no such statement was ever made by me.

subdebate.1.para: Mr. SPEAKER(Hon. G. J. Bell).I have received from the right honorable member for Cowper (.Sir Earle Page) an intimation that he desires to move the adjournment of the House for the purpose of discussing a definite matter of urgent public importance, namely, " The necessity for substituting a plan of rationalization of transport and of voluntary regulation of petro] consumption by and under the direction of the industries themselves, with a view to stopping the alarming growth of unemployment in the transport industry and consequent dislocation of the national economy and the national war effort, in the place of the Government's plan for the compulsory rationing of petrol to secure savings in Australia ".

talk.start.para: .- I move -

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: -Is the motion supported ?

para.inline: Five honorable members having risen in support of the motion,

talk.start.para: - I shall advance several reasons for this motion. First, I direct attention to the extraordinary importance of the subject, for it is obvious to every one in the community that we must have sufficient petrol for defence purposes, and also that we must provide employment for the 365,000 people engaged in our road transport industry. My second reason is that the subject is extraordinarily urgent, for the longer we are without a definite policy on the subject the greater will be the momentum of the unemployment which is being caused, and the more serious will be the losses of those who have invested their money in our transport system. A very serious dislocation of the efficient organization that has been developed over a number of years is also occurring and the longer this is allowed to continue the greater will be the difficulty in restoring it to its full functioning, which I am sure will be absolutely needed before the war is over. Further, I differ from the Government as to the principle of the methods it is adopting to meet the situation that has arisen. I believe that the compulsory rationing of petrol in Australia will be difficult to administer, and police, and that it may very easily be unduly harsh in its application. I am satisfied also that the system that has been adopted by the Government may result in the goodwill and co-operation which a large section of our motor vehicle users and traders have hitherto shown towards the Government war effort being replaced by either sullen acquiesence in what U being done or active evasion by people who consider that they are being unjustly treated. The results desired by the Government may be more effectively and quickly obtained by an elastic scheme of voluntary regulation within the industry itself. Government schemes must necessarily be rigid and less rapid in action than voluntary schemes. They must also cause anomalies which can only be remedied with difficulty.

speech.para: I do not think, that *he importance of our road transport system to the national life of our country is generally realized. The only true comparison that I can make is to liken it to the blood circulation system of the human body. Damage to that system is . much more likely to be far-reaching in its effects and to have serious repercussions than is damage to any single organ of the body. Just as the blood system touches every organ of the body, so does our road transport system touch every activity of our national economy. We should, therefore, exercise extraordinary care in adopting any system that is designed to effect a curtailment of the activities of our road transport system, in order to ensure that any such action is taken in a way which will be least harmful to the whole organization. Unless we exercise this vigilance, we may damage not only the transport interests directly concerned, but also all those interests which are essential to the maintenance and development of our national war effort.

It seems to me that, most of the difficulties arising at present in this regard are due to the narrow view that has been taken of the problem. The tendency is to treat the rationing of petrol as an isolated subject, rather than as an action which must be adjusted to the fundamental and essential activities of the whole community. Rationing in itself is not a cure for our condition. It may help to tide us over a temporary emergency, but it is no m'ore a cure than the indiscriminate bleeding practised by my colleagues in the medical profession on their patients hundreds of years ago was a cure for al] bodily ills. A good many people died under that treatment. An illustration that rationing is not the best, way to deal with this matter is provided by the fact that the war circumstances have already brought about a very considerable amount of voluntary rationing already; it is stated that the consumption of petrol by private and commercial users has fallen by 25 per cent, since the outbreak of the war, that there has been a 45 per cent, decrease of employment in the industry, the registration of new motor cars has fallen by 75 per cent, and the whole motor transport industry is in a state of chaos. We must look at this matter from the broadest possible view-point before we take a step which might have very undesirable consequences. I should like to point out how much has been done during the last 20 or 30 years to make the road transport system of Australia one of the most important arches of our whole national economic structure. During the last 150 years a remarkable change has taken place in the standards of living of the people, their comfort, the manner of their life and the variety of their food. In a large measure this has been due to the improvement of world transport, the harnessing of steam, electricity and oil and the advent of the internal combustion engine. In the last 40 years the extraordinary improvement of road transport, particularly noticeable in the last two decades, has transformed commerce and production especially in countries of huge expanse such as Australia, the United States of America and Canada. I venture to say that in considering the subject of petrol rationing we should not make comparisons with countries smaller than our own, such as New Zealand and Great Britain, which are relatively better served by railways than is Australia, and have more coastal sea-borne traffic. Let us give thought for a moment to the tremendous progress that has been made in this industry within recent years. Only 40 years ago the first motor car came to Australia, and only in the last 20 years has the motor industry become a big factor in this country. To-day, the capital invested in the industry is staggering. Practically all of that money has been privately subscribed, and the investments have proved profitable. I find on examination that to-day the capital invested in the actual business of road transport approximates £200,000,000. In. Australia to-day there are something like 850,000 registered motor cars, lorries and vehicles of a value of at least £80,000,000. During the last 20 years something like £40,000,000 has been provided by the Commonwealth a.nd another £60,000,000 has been provided by the States under the federal aid roads scheme and their ordinary activities. In other words the road transport industry represents an investment of a total of approximately £400,000,000, which about equals the total capitalization of our Australian railways of £350,000,000, and is twelve times the capitalization of the whole of the shipping on the Australian register. The effect of this huge expenditure of money in connexion with the transport of this country has been to stimulate development and production in areas previously unthought of. It has enabled us to tap resources hitherto regarded as inaccessible and has transformed progress in commerce, particularly in the last ten years, during which practically no railways have been constructed. It has permitted the continual expansion of suburban factories and dwellings around capital cities, and has enabled the population to live in semi-rural conditions, while at the same time enabling extraordinary growth of country towns which .previously were stagnating. Towns like Grafton, Casino, Taree, Kempsey and Coffs Harbour have doubled their population during that period, because the utilization of motor transport has enabled the people to go 20 or 30 miles farther to get their timber resources from stands never before capable of exploitation. It has enabled dairymen to settle on land 70 or 80 miles away from a dairy factory, whereas in the horse and buggy days the limit was 20 or 30 miles. "We must do nothing to damage that structure; we must do everything in our power to develop and expand it. We cannot go back on our tracks if we wish to retain the solvency and production of this country. It is obvious, of course, that we must have sufficient reserves of petrol for our defence needs; but at the same time we must not forget that the future of this country, as well as its present defence, depends to a great degree upon the maintenance of adequate supplies of petrol to business and commercial users. Three reasons have been given for the imposition of rationing and the need to make drastic curtailments of our petrol imports. It is said, firstly, that there is a shortage of storage facilities in Australia; secondly, that there is a shortage of tanker shipping; and, thirdly, that this action is necessary in order to conserve foreign exchange. With regard to storage facilities, I point out that the Lyons-Page Government had definite plans to increase the number of storage reservoirs. How far has the present Government carried out those plans? I was informed last Monday by the president of the Service Garages Association that its members have storage space for approximately 30,000,000 gallons of petrol, only one-half of which is at present being used. That space would be invaluable for the storage of petrol for use by our mechanical arms of the defence forces should it be desirable to move troops rapidly in country centres.

talk.start.para: - That is a grossly extravagant statement.

- The association states definitely that there is to-day in garages throughout Australia unused storage space of about half of the 28,000,000 or 30,000,000 gallons. Most of the storage tanks installed in country garages are not more than 25 per cent, to 40 per cent. full. Then, there are other means of increasing our storage facilities which should be explored. I understand that an offer has recently been made by a large construction company to build, inside three or four months, 100 concrete tanks, each capable of holding 1,000,000 gallons, for £5,000 each. If that offer were accepted we could double our present bulk storage facilities and distribute it more safely. The second reason advanced for the imposition of petrol rationing is the shortage of tanker shipping. I am informed that tankers are still fairly freely available, but that the present system of discharging their cargo at different ports is wasteful. Under the present arrangements, a tanker may be hired by any one of the four or five major oil companies and unload its cargo at the depots of that company at Rockhampton, Brisbane, Sydney, Newcastle and Melbourne before returning empty. If arrangements were made between the companies for tankers to discharge the whole of their cargo at one port, for all of the oil companies instead of for one particular organization, the total quantity of petrol transported by them could be doubled because of the time saved on the Australian coast. The Government should seriously consider the utilization of tanker space in the best possible way. The third reason advanced for petrol rationing is the need . for the conservation of foreign exchange. In regard to that I am in a position to say only that unless we do something to enable us to use to the fullest degree what productive resources we have in this country, insufficient wealth will be produced to supply foreign exchange for our own needs. We must do everything we can to improve our position in this regard. I fully realize that the consumption of petrol by the civil population under present circumstances must be reduced in order to ensure a sufficient margin for defence purposes. We should however, immediately do everything possible to build up a large reserve of petrol in this country in order to lessen the curtailment of supplies to the civil population at the earliest possible moment. As I have said, the war has already brought about a considerable reduction of the use of petrol by the public generally. The additional tax of 3d. a gallon imposed by the Government as a means of increasing the revenue for war purposes, the extra 4d. imposed by the oil companies because of higher shipping charges, and the depreciation of sterling and Australian exchange in relation to the dollar, have had a cumulative effect in bringing about a reduction of the demand for petrol. In addition to this, the war has caused considerable dislocation of exporting and importing businesses and that has had its effect on petrol consumption. Many exporting and importing firms to-day enjoy nothing like the volume of business they enjoyed before the war, and many have had to make very serious reductions of staff. The heavy general taxation imposed by Australian governments has also lessened the amount of money available for pleasure riding and, in addition, a considerable number of young men - nearly 200,000 - are now in military camps. Many of those young men would be large users of pleasure cars. It is true that the reductions brought about in this way will offset our heavy defence requirements, but, of course, not completely. A further reduction, and a wider use of what is available, can be obtained through the organization of the use of petrol for private and business purposes in such a way as to eliminate waste in every direction, abolish duplication, and wipe out unhealthy and excessive competition.
- What about the employment issue there?

- I shall deal with that in a moment or two. A number of methods should be used simultaneously. The Commonwealth and State Governments could do their share by eliminating waste in government services. The locations of military camps affect the rate of petrol consumption in the defence services to a great degree. Many camps are distant from railway stations, with the result that large quantities of petrol are used for the purpose of transporting officers and men between railway stations and the camps.

speech.para: One instance I shall cite is that of the Evans Head training camp, which is 30 miles from the nearest railway centre. It could have been conveniently situated at Coffs Harbour,' Casino, Grafton, or Kempsey, or a dozen different places which are close to a railway line. [Leave to continue given.] Petrol is wasted also by the use of heavy lorries to transport small parcels to military camps. Such parcels should be carried on motor cycles whenever possible. No blame should attach to any Minister for wastage which occurs in this way; the matter should bc dealt with by sergeants and sergeant-majors. Another practice that should be discontinued is the transport of heavy loads by defence lorries on routes running parallel with main .railway lines. Such loads could be moved by rail ; the extra work involved in transhipment from lorries to railway trucks would be more than offset by the saving of petrol.

An appeal should be made to the patriotism of private consumers of petrol in order to induce them to use petroldriven vehicles as little as possible. More force would be given to the appeal if the Government could first say that it had instituted economies in its own services. The appeal could be launched by means of wireless broadcasts and publicity in newspapers and could be strengthened by obtaining the co-operation of motor-trade organizations. Consumers could be asked to drive their vehicles at a. more economic speed, which would tend also to decrease the accident rate on public roads. They could be asked to curtail motor travelling for pleasure. In many cases, one car could be used in place of two or three for combined family outings to the seaside. Speed contests for petroldriven vehicles could be banned by State laws or Commonwealth regulations. A definite limitation of trading hours at motor garages and service stations on both week-days and Sundays might also effect, an economy. Speed limits have already been fixed in New South Wales and trading hours at petrol stations have been reduced in Victoria.
The most effective way to reduce petrol consumption would be to organize commercial transport services throughout

Australia in order to prevent overlapping. This work could be delegated to State transport boards, which could be strengthened and assisted by representatives of motor-trading organizations and commercial petrol users. In order to illustrate the way in which transport services overlap, I shall quote from a letter I have received from the manager of one of the dairy companies in my electorate. I asked that gentleman to give me some instances of overlapping and he responded by giving me five. His letter stated -

quote.para: Lawrence has three separate services and also a mail service which carries cream. Contractors for Grafton, Ulmarra and Foley Brothers all run a lorry each, and none of them' is paying:, whereas one lorry could carry the whole of the cream for eight months in the year.

speech.para: Lawrence is 20 miles from Grafton and it would be possible to save 700 palIons of petrol monthly if the services on the five routes mentioned were coordinated. I believe that if similar overlapping throughout the northern districts of New South Wales were eliminated, the saving effected would amount to 1,000,000 gallons a year.

talk.start.para: - It would also cause the dismissal of many motor drivers and others depending upon the services for a living.

- Not as much as rationing. I shall deal with that problem later. Action could be taken in city areas. Wastage occurs in cases where several milk delivery cars visit the same area; arrangements could be made for one car to do the work of all of them in that locality.

speech.para: The distribution of goods by retail trading establishments to suburban areas also involves a great deal of waste. In order to prevent this, the firms could establish a joint clearing house from which goods could be taken to their destinations. In that way, one lorry could perhaps do the amount of work in one suburb that is now done by three or four vehicles that cover the same ground. This would effect a saving of thousands of gallons of petrol annually.

The economies effected in these ways need not last only for the duration of the war. They could be made permanent in order to help the nation to pay its com mitments arising out of the war. Waste could also be prevented by eliminating unnecessary competition between the State railway systems and private transport companies using petrol-driven vehicles. This would be particularly effective if applied to interstate traffic.

As the Minister has said, men might be thrown out of employment and motor vehicles might be forced into idleness if these restrictions were enforced. But some of these vehicles and many men could be used for defence purposes. Other vehicles could be held in reserve in order to replace those which would go out of service as the result of wear and tear. In order to show how a use could be found for displaced vehicles - and this can be multiplied all over Australia - I refer to a country district where there are a sawmill employing twelve men, five dairy farms, and a number of stockmen, making a total of seventeen families. Most of these families own dilapidated motor cars which they drive to the nearest town at regular intervals, thus using large quantities of petrol. Lorries which had been put out of service in other areas could be used to provide a cheap and profitable transport service for that and other districts, thus eliminating the use of the numerous privately-owned vehicles.

It might be necessary to impose a higher rate of tax on petrol used in nonessential activities if other measures failed to cause a satisfactory reduction of consumption. The tax could be levied universally, with rebates for commercial users and operators such as farmers, commercial travellers and lorry owners who depend upon their vehicles for a livelihood. All the measures that I have suggested so far could be put into operation immediately.

I also had in mind two long-range proposals which, although they might not give immediate relief, would benefit the nation eventually. The first of these is to increase as quickly as possible the rate of manufacture of power alcohol in its various forms. I am glad to know that the Government is already taking action to bring about such an increase. The second proposal relates to the use of producer gas units. These units will not come into general use unless prices fall considerably below their present level.

The Government could pay a subsidy on their manufacture and standardize the various types in order to reduce their retail price to £15 or £10. No man, struggling for a livelihood, could afford to pay £60, £70 or £100 for one of these machines.

The expedients which I have suggested would reduce the rate of petrol consumption without imposing hardships on commercial users such as timbermillers and dairy-farmers, who depend almost entirely upon motor transport for a livelihood." The prosperity and integrity of the nation depend in a great measure upon these people, and they should be provided with all of the fuel that they require. In time of war many industries may need more petrol than they use in time of peace in order to help the war effort. The timber industry has been expanded in order to supply an additional 200,000,000 feet of timber in place of overseas timber which can no longer be imported. The value to the country of this increase will more than offset any loss of dollar exchange due to the consumption of larger quantities of petrol for transporting timber.

The implementation of my proposals would meet, with the approval of almost everyone in the transport industry in Australia. The Government should first decide upon a definite policy. Then it should introduce a scheme which could be strengthened without costly changes of administration. Industries handling petrol should be used as far as possible to regulate its use. The Government should also make a definite plan now for the expansion of industry as soon as war conditions permit. Australia will not be able to wage war successfully unless this important problem of national economy is dealt with immediately.

talk.start.para: . - There can be no dispute about the important part that transport, particularly petrol-using transport, plays in our industrial and social economy. I shall be very happy to elaborate the theme upon which the right honorable member for Cowper (Sir Earle Page) based his speech in that connexion. The Government, and

speech.para: I may modestly say the Minister concerned, did appreciate the important position that transport has in our economy in time of war and the injury that would be done to the whole community if transport facilities were unduly restricted. Therefore, we were reluctant to introduce any petrol rationing scheme and because of our reluctance we have left ourselves open to criticism. I was pleased to note that the right honorable member for Cowper did not deny the desirability of reducing petrol consumption. He merely suggested various methods by which reductions could be effected. In dealing with the subject of unemployment which might arise from the curtailment of transport facilities, he overlooked what ought to be an elementary fact - that the effect on employment of reduced petrol consumption would be the same whatever method might be employed.

talk.start.para: - Not necessarily.

- Indeed, in some of the illustrations which the right honorable gentleman gave this was abundantly clear. He spoke of four lorries engaged upon transporting cream to a butter factory when the work could bc done effectively by one. If that means anything, it means that, if the suggested economy wore effected, three drivers could be displaced and the business of the service station associated with the maintenance of the lorries would bo reduced. In replying to the points made by the right honorable gentleman, my style is somewhat cramped because, as I stated yesterday, the Control Board which is at present devising a plan of rationing, pursuant to the Government's directions that there must be an economy of 33$ per r.ent. in the use of petrol for civil purposes, is sitting in Melbourne at this moment, and I expect its report to-morrow The Government does not yet know what proposals the board will make, and I am therefore handicapped in discussing the alternative suggestions put forward here this afternoon.
- Will the scheme be announced in detail before the elections?

- The honorable member is now trying to obtain by subtle means information which I am. not able to give him. I take this opportunity to emphasize that the Government, so far from having been guilty of contemplating a plan that would inflict injury on a great body of people in Australia, has left itself open to serious criticism because of its reluctance to take action. If there is any matter upon which the Government can claim acquittal without a stain on its character it is this one. Honorable members know that, on the outbreak of war, it was found necessary to pool the foreign exchange resources of the Empire in order that we might acquire by purchase those commodities which are essential to the conduct of the war. Australia is a partner in that Empire pool, and one of the conditions upon which we were granted participation in Empire resources was that we, in common with the other parts of the Empire, should use every endeavour to curtail the purchase of peace-time requirements so that our resources might be used for the purchase of essential war needs. In application of that policy many restrictions have been placed upon the purchase of peacetime requirements. Newsprint has been rationed, and consumption reduced by 35 per cent. The importation of motor cars has been reduced by 45 per cent., as has also the importation of some important textiles. Certain other goods, previously imported to the value of £10,000,000 a year, have been banned altogether. The petrol rationing scheme has been on the stocks since the outbreak of war. On the 2nd and 3rd September last, there was a conference between the Commonwealth Oil Board; and representatives of the various State transport organizations, which considered a scheme of petrol rationing somewhat similar to that now suggested. The fact that, up to now, we have not actively moved in that direction does at least acquit the Government of a lack of concern for the interest of those whose livelihood depends upon the motor industry.

speech.para: However, there is more in this than the conservation of exchange, both sterling and dollar. A new issue has obtruded itself because of the increasing petrol needs of the defence forces. I am not at liberty to say what those needs would be in the event of general mobilization, but I can say that, if they were

Sir Frederick Stewart.fully met, they would absorb a very great proportion of the petrol stored in the Commonwealth. There is also the further point that no one can guarantee with certainty the uninterrupted receipt of seaborne supplies of petrol, or of any other commodity.

talk.start.para: - Can the Minister say whether the Government is making any arrangements for petrol storage, other than in coastal tanks, which are so vulnerable?

- Yes, and I shall deal with that in a little while. For the reasons I have stated, the Government was most reluctantly compelled to decide that the consumption of petrol for civil purposes must be reduced by 33^ per cent, as compared with the pre-war figure. It was obviously impossible for Cabinet itself to work out the complex .plan which would be necessary, and so a control board was formed on which there were two representatives of petrol users. This board met, and made certain preliminary suggestions as to the method by which the Government's decision should be carried out. Those suggestions were not endorsed by the Government, and the board was enlarged to include three more representatives of petrol users, so that it should be directly representative of the .petrol users of Australia. The board is now meeting in Melbourne, and the Government expects to receive its report to-morrow. The Government has not varied its decision that there should be a reduction of consumption by 33£ per cent. It is, however, quite prepared to consider alternative methods by which the same end may be achieved, methods which, in the opinion of the direct representatives of the users of petrol, will cause the least inconvenience to the community.
- What will a saving ot 33^ per cent, represent?
- The normal consumption of petrol is 360.000,000 gallons a year. We are trying to save 120,000,000 gallons a year.
- What will that represent in foreign exchange?

- I cannot say precisely. I point out that, even if we achieve a saving of 33£ per cent, of the quantity of petrol used for civil purposes, we shall not save a proportionate amount of foreign exchange as compared with pre-war expenditure. One reason for this is the greatly increased consumption of petrol for defence purposes, and another is the increased overseas cost of petrol, the price of which has risen by 3d. a gallon since the beginning of the war.

speech.para: The Government is also taking constructive action to meet the situation, and is seeking to exploit in every way possible means for the production of substitute fuels from local resources. Our activities in this direction cover four or five fields. As the result of arrangements made between the Commonwealth Government and the Government of New South Wales, the Newnes shale oil-field, which was out of production for some years, is again being worked. Had it not been for an unfortunate mechanical mishap a few weeks ago, the ultimate refinement of the petrol for commercial use would have been commenced last Saturday. It ha3 now been postponed for a fortnight. The output of petrol from this source is expected to amount to 10,000,000 gallons a year, and this rate of production will be increased. We are expecting and hoping that other shale-fields in Australia will be developed. In order to encourage that development, the Government decided a few weeks ago to extend the protection, which it is giving to the Newnes enterprise, to any other concern in Australia which engages upon the production of oil fa* om shale or coal. This means that any producer of shale oil or coal oil will be entitled to protection against imported petrol to the amount of 7|d. a gallon, and will obtain a remission of 5-Jd. a gallon excise as compared with petrol refined locally from imported crude oil. The Government has also increased the excise remission on benzolathe fuel which is manufactured -by the gas companies, and we are hoping, by cooperation with those companies, to reach an annual production of 4,000,000 gallons of benzola. For months past, the Government has been in consultation with the sugar companies and distilleries in connexion with the production of power alcohol. In the past, this fuel has been produced at the rate of about 2,000,000 gallons a year, and it is hoped to increase the rate of production considerably. We have encouraged the companies to increase their storage capacity, so that, as soon as we are able to arrange for additional supplies of raw material, production may be increased. A committee of inquiry, under the presidency of the Assistant Minister for Supply (M*r. Fadden), will be constituted to encourage the production of power alcohol from various commodities, not excluding our surplus wheat.

The right honorable member for Cowper suggested that the Government might give more attention to proposals for encouraging the production of producergas units. Many months ago, the Government encouraged the production of hundreds of producer1, gas units by a somewhat novel, but, I contend, effective method. We induced a number of manufacturers to make units on the understanding that, if they did not sell them to the public within a certain period, the Government would buy them. In this way a great many units of an approved type have been made, and are in use in various parts of Australia. Other manufacturers have now entered the field, and we are expecting that this fuel will become a permanent substitute for a considerable portion of the petrol which we have been importing up to date, thus enabling us to save some part of the millions of pounds which has been going overseas every year to foreign petrol corporations. I can claim, therefore, that no one has more understanding of, or sympathy with, the motor industry than have members of the Government, or a greater reluctance to affect injuriously the prosperity of that industry. Certainly, no one in thi9 House has more personal sympathy with those engaged in the industry thaw I have. This is the best assurance I can offer that the rationing proposals, reluctantly adopted, will be administered in the most, sympathetic way.

talk.start.para: .- The motion of the right honorable member for Cowper (Sir Earle Page) should commend itself to honorable members of all parties. I believe that if a vote of the House were taken it would clearly indicate to the Minister for

speech.para: Supply and Development (Sir Frederick Stewart) that the drastic petrol rationing scheme proposed by the Government is quite out of favour with the people of Australia, and that there is no justification for it. With due respect to the honorable gentleman, who is a hardworking Minister, I am not satisfied with his speech; it contained too many pious hopes. The honorable gentleman expressed the hope and the confident belief that additional shale-oil fields will be opened up, and said that, but for a mechanical accident at Newnes, that field would to-day be in production. He made the further statement that for many months the Government had been in constant touch with the sugar companies, and that full and scientific consideration is to be given to the possibility of increasing the production of power alcohol, from various commodities, including surplus wheat. We have had statements of that kind ad nauseam. The Government has not come forward with a clear-cut policy, but on the contrary has made contradictory statements which have undermined the confidence of those engaged in the transport industries. These industries, according to the right honorable member for Cowper, have already reduced the volume of their employment by nearly 45 per cent.
