Indeed, in this matter, as in most of the other matters handled by the Government, hesitation, vacillation, and procrastination seem to have been the outstanding features of ministerial policy. Characteristic of its blundering was its handling of the Department of Information, a dictatorship over which it gave to Sir Keith Murdoch, the controller of a monopolistic group of newspapers and broadcasting stations in this country. The motor industry is of too great importance to Australia to be handled as the Government obviously has handled it. Directly invested in the motor transport industry and associated industries is the sum of £200,000,000; and 265,000 persons, or 13 per cent, of all wage and salary earners in Australia, are engaged in it. In a paragraph that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of the 24th November, 1939, it was stated that an estimate had revealed that a 10 per cent, loss of employment would be caused by a 20 per cent, rationing of petrol consumption, and that this would involve the loss of £2,700,000 in wages. The motor industry, with all its ramifications, provides revenue amounting to £31,000,000 annually, or nearly 26 per cent, of the total revenue collected by the Governments of the Commonwealth and the States. The executive of the Associated Motor Transport Industry of New South Wales, in a considered statement published in the Sydney Morning Herald of the 31st July last, pointed out that a 33 per cent, cut of petrol supplies would throw out of employment in Australia 26,000 drivers and owner-drivers. Different figures have been given as to' the unemployment that would be caused by the application of the policy of the Government. Those figures quoted by the right honorable member for Cowper will bear investigation. Severe restrictions would seriously affect the economic life of all industries, and be extremely prejudicial to many thousands of persons who are in employment to-day, as well as to the thousands of purchasers of machines on time-payment, who will find it almost impossible to meet their commitments, and who will be involved in a sacrifice, because so many second-hand machines will be offered for sale on an unresponsive market.

The Australian Labour party has clearly enunciated its policy in regard to the necessity to adopt an extensive oil storage scheme. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Curtin) in his policy speech in 1937, and prior to that date, stressed the vital necessity to accumulate reserves of oil to meet a period of emergency, in order to avoid a haphazard, last-minute rush by the Government to institute drastic rationing of petrol consumption, such as is now proposed. The predicament in which the Government now finds itself is the result of its failure to take practical steps along the lines then suggested. On the 27 th November. 1939, the Minister for Supply said -

quote.para: In view of the possibility of petrol rationing next year, the Supply Department had decided upon an extensive development of substitute fuels.

speech.para: What practical steps have been taken in that direction? Apart from communicating by letter with the Colonial Sugar

Refining Company Limited and other sugar companies, nothing of a practical nature has been accomplished since the day on which war broke out. In the Sydney Morning Herald of the 27th November, 1939, the Minister said that the Government would not impose rationing unless compelled to do so by circumstances, those circumstances being - 1, necessity for the conservation of dollar exchange; 2, the possibility of nonavailability of tankers to bring petrol to Australia; and 3, the needs of the defence forces. I am not convinced by what the Minister has said, or by anything that I have heard from other Ministers, that there is the slightest justification from the point of view of dollar exchange, the tanker position, and defence needs for rationing to the degree proposed by the Government. The fundamental benefit that would accrue from the rationing of petrol consumption in Australia would be the awakening of people of Australia to the necessity to make some sacrifice in their mode of living, and to appreciation of the fact that this country, although far removed from the actual theatre of war, is nevertheless at war ; but it cannot be said to be justified to the extent proposed. The Government has failed to convince the House that petrol rationing is necessary for the conservation of dollar exchange. This argument, which is often used by Ministers, is a myth. In effect, approximately Sd. a gallon has to be remitted in payment for every gallon of petrol brought into this country, plus shipping and exchange, and the whole of the proceeds of all companies are remitted in sterling to London, the bulk of the petrol supplies to Australia coming from non-dollar countries.

talk.start.para: - They are paid for in dollars.

- At the outbreak or war, Great Britain had 3,000,000 tons of tankers. From September, 1939, to May, 1940, Great Britain lost 4.5 per cent, of its tanker fleet, France a little over 1 per cent., and Norway about 3 per cent. Since the invasion of the low countries by Germany, the tanker fleets of Norway, Denmark and France have been in the service of Great Britain and the Empire, with the result that to-day

speech.para: Great Britain has at its disposal 6,256,000 tons of tankers. This information has been made available by the petroleum press service, the authentic channel through which are published facts regarding the petroleum industry of the world. [Leave to continue given.'] The United States of America, which produces 60 per cent, of the world's petroleum, has a large fleet of tankers. The use of common sense will convince anybody that, because of the inability of the United States of America to ship oil to Europe, that country must have a. very large surplus of tankers. Because of the position in Europe, and the fact that American shipping has been cut off, the price of petroleum in the United States of America is most satisfactory. The glut on the market, due to inability to export, has resulted in production having overtaken consumption in the United States of America and the Netherlands East Indies, which are the principal producing countries; consequently, whoever attempts to justify rationing in Australia on the basis of the availability of tankers can be proved to be working on incorrect facts. There is scope for considerable expansion in respect of storage. The Government has asked the oil companies to utilize their storage tanks to the fullest capacity. I have been informed that the Shell Oil Company has its storage tanks utilized to 82 per cent, of their capacity; the figure in respect of the Vacuum Oil Company is 60 per cent. ; Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited 40 per cent.; and other companies 23 percent. This matter requires investigation. It is true that thedifferent companies have gone to considerable trouble to increase their storage capacity. One of the biggest companies in Australia has almost completed the installation of additional storage at the request of the Commonwealth Government. But has the Government done everything possible in this regard? I am not satisfied that it has handled this matter with the enthusiasm for which the Minister for Supply was noted in respect of the national insurance scheme. If the companies marketed a one-grade petrol, a large number of garage tanks throughout Australia would be available to be filled on behalf of the

Government and sealed securely for future use. This, plus hoarded supplies - and hoarding has been encouraged among the consumers of Australia - would enable up to nine months' supply of petrol to be held. Conditions in England are entirely different from those in the Commonwealth. Australia, with its farflung areas and the demands of timber merchants, dairymen, farmers and others who are dependent upon oil for their livelihood, has needs different from those of a small, compact area like England. I believe that the Government will make a grave blunder if it imposes rationing to the extent of 33^ per cent. If some rationing scheme be necessary, it should be possible to introduce a system which will be less severe than the public has been led to expect. I have not been convinced by the Minister's speech. He admitted that he himself was largely in the dark, because this matter had been handed over to a board. Before this country is plunged into an election campaign, the people should have some details of the proposed petrol rationing scheme so that they may vote upon it. If we can take statements in the press as a criterion of public opinion, it is clear that a vast majority of the travelling public will reject the proposed rationing scheme, and the Government which sponsored it.

talk.start.para: . - I do not wish any remarks of mine to embarrass the Government, particularly as I do not question its bona fides in relation to the matter before the House. The rationing of petrol is a subject of great concern to the public generally, because vital interests are at stake. For that reason some credit is due to the right honorable member for Cowper (.Sir Earle Page) for bringing this matter forward. I shall not, at this juncture, support any scheme of rationing of which I know nothing. Even the Minister for Supply and Development (Sir Frederick Stewart) himself knows nothing of what is proposed.
- He knows, but he will not tell us.

speech.para: Mir. PERKINS.- Before the Minister sanctions any scheme of rationing, I hope that he will give to the proposal of the right honorable member for Cowper his most serious consideration. The original scheme of the Minister provided for sufficient petrol to enable private users of cars to travel 40 miles a week.

talk.start.para: - I did not bring that proposal forward.
- That scheme has, however, been thrown overboard.
- I threw it overboard.

- The scheme that u to come forward to-morrow may also be thrown overboard. The proposal to limit private motorists to 40 miles a week was ridiculous, although the Minister might have thought that it was sound.
- I did not.

speech.para: Mir. PERKINS.- The proposal was ludicrous. In my electorate there are people who live 100 miles from the railhead, and others whose homes are situated 50 or 60 miles from the nearest township. Of what use to them would be a scheme which enabled them to travel only 40 miles a week? There is no guarantee that any new scheme which will emanate from the board will not be equally ridiculous, because I have no great confidence in its members. Most of them live in the cities and are not sufficiently acquainted with country conditions to propound a scheme to cover country users of petrol. Any system of rationing which gives the same quantity of petrol to all users of cars, irrespective of where they live, would be most unjust. Every day one can see on the Sydney Harbour Bridge, hundreds of cars each containing only one person. In a district well served by trams, trains, omnibuses and steamers, many men still drive their own cars to and from their employment. Their position is entirely different from that of men who live, say, 8 or 10 miles from the nearest country town, and would have to walk if not provided with more than sufficient petrol to convey them 40 miles a week. Any scheme of petrol rationing which is brought forward will need to be examined most carefully.

I do not altogether agree with the remarks of the right honorable member for Cowper as to the effect on employment of the rationing of petrol, although I admit that any system of rationing must cause some unemployment. Already work on road construction has been seriously curtailed, and many men have been thrown out of work. Even without compulsory rationing, there has already been a considerable reduction of the consumption of patrol. The Minister may be able to say to what degree the public has voluntarily reduced its travelling and saved petrol. I imagine that the saving is appreciable. That opinion is based on my own observations, and the statements of people who say that the traffic on the south coast roads of New South "Wales has fallen by 50 per cent, during recent months. If voluntary rationing has had that effect, it should not be necessary to take such drastic action as has been rumoured in the press in order to bring about a 33$ per cent, reduction of Australia's petrol consumption. As the right honorable member for Cowper pointed out, there are many ways in which petrol can be conserved without causing the hardship which the scheme envisaged would entail. For instance, by a system of zoning, it should be possible to reduce (the amount of travelling now done by milk vendors and other trades-people. By eliminating overlapping, beneficial results could be achieved. I admit that there must be some restriction of the use of petrol, and that, whatever form the restriction takes, there will be some further unemployment; but we should reduce as much as possible the hardship inflicted on the community. I hope that the Minister will not adopt the attitude that whatever the newly constituted board proposes must necessarily be right, but will give consideration to other proposals. I believe that an appeal to the motoring public to economize in the use of petrol would effect a great saving of motor spirit.

There are great possibilities in regard to the extraction of oil from coal. I have brought under the notice of the present Minister, as well as his predecessor, one such scheme. Some honorable members accompanied me on a visit to a plant for extracting oil from coal conducted by a young Sydney man, who claimed that his process would enable oil to be obtained from coal at a cost of not more than 5d. a gallon. He has received no encouragement from the Commonwealth Government, although the Government of New Zealand was willing to investigate his claim. I have asked the Minister to inquire into this claim, but apparently it will not do anything in the matter unless it first learns the secret of his process of extraction. If the inventor of the process gives away that secret, he will be undone. The Government which gave to the proprietors of the Newnes project a grant of £300,000 should do something to encourage others like the young man to whom I have referred. I am convinced that there is something in his claim.

talk.start.para: - He now has as much protection as is given to the Newnes people.

- That may be so theoretically, but he is a poor man; whereas the company which the Government assisted was not without considerable funds. It is true that the Government sent an officer to investigate this man's process, but only to reject his claim. I again plead that his case be investigated, because I believe that it is worthy of the Government's interest.

talker.role: Leader of the Australian. Labour party - nonCommunist
talker.name: BEASLEY, John
Mr BEASLEY

talk.start.para: . - Eleven months have elapsed since war was declared, but it would appear that the Government is no further ahead to-day in respect of a policy for safeguarding fuel supplies than it was at the outbreak of hostilities, although the fact must have been obvious at the outset that problems of foreign exchange and the provision of uninterrupted supplies of oil fuel would have to be faced. If the Government did not realize the importance of those two factors early in the war, it had no proper conception of its responsibilities. The Government has taken nine months to consider these matters.
- The position has deteriorated lately.

- The Government claims to have done well in disposing of Australia's primary products, but, after providing for the full requirements of sterling countries, arrangements could have been made with the surplus to provide for the necessary foreign exchange, thus making provision against the necessity for rationing petrol. These foreign exchanges could have been built up in friendly countries. The necessity to ensure continuous supplies of petrol, and protect trade routes against the enemy, should have been obvious to the Government from the beginning.
- Who was the enemy?
- If the honorable gentleman does not know who Australia's potential enemy is, he never will know.

speech.para: The contradictory statements of Ministers in regard to fuel oil supplies have made them ridiculous in the eyes of the people. Last week the Minister for Supply and Development (Sir Frederick Stewart) said that the public need not be unduly alarmed at the decision to ration petrol, because the effect of the Government's proposal might not be so serious as was generally believed. On the day that he made that statement, the Minister for Air (Mr. Fairbairn), speaking at Perth, said that the rationing scheme would have to be more drastic than was at first contemplated. When two such contradictory statements by Ministers appear in the press on the samo day, the public cannot be other than uncertain as to what is intended. As reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of the 2nd July, the Minister for Supply and Development deplored any tendency towards panic. He then said -

quote.para: Perhaps the best re assurance that I can give is the fact that, with complete knowledge of the Government's intention, X myself recently bought a new car.

speech.para: As I understand that he has since denied making that statement, I leave it to that reputable journal to say whether or not its report was correct. I imagine that the statement was made by the Minister in an interview with representatives of the press. With such contradictions before them, the motorists of this country do not know whether they are going or coming.

If the rationing of petrol be necessary, why did not the Government take steps nine months ago to introduce a moderate scheme of rationing, instead of inflicting on the public the drastic scheme which has now been outlined in the press ?

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable member think that that should have been done?

- Had a moderate scheme of rationing been introduced following the declaration -of war, the commercial interests of this country could have arranged to equip their vehicles with producer-gas units, and the change-over from petrol to producer gas could have taken place gradually. By that means drastic rationing now might have been avoided. For its neglect in this matter the Government must accept the responsibility. It should have foreseen the present situation, and taken precautionary steps. However, it seems clear now that petrol is to be rationed, largely because of the greatlyincreased consumption of the commodity by the Air Force and other services. Probably that increased consumption will more than counteract the saving of petrol by the public, following the raising of the price of petrol and the application of voluntary rationing.

speech.para: A matter to which the Government should direct its attention is the position of people who have entered into obligations in relation to the installation of producer gas units in an effort to meet the wishes of the authorities. Some people have, after considerable investigation, established plants to" manufacture producer gas units and other people have invested capital in partially installing such plants. They are both in difficulty now, as they do not feel justified in proceeding further, because they are unable to ascertain the exact intentions of the Government. There is undoubtedly a feeling abroad that the Government does not know what to do about this subject, in that it has not announced the degree of rationing which is to be applied. Its vacillating attitude has left many people in suspense. For this reason, I submit that individuals and companies which have almost completed their preparations for either the manufacture or the installation of new equipment should be given special consideration. The statements of responsible Ministers seem to carry little weight. People are being denied information which should be made available to them. This uncertainty has led to delay in the manufacture of producer gas units. Steps should have been taken a considerable time ago to encourage the marketing of this equipment at reasonable rates. As the right honorable member for Cowper has said, the Government should have announced its willingness to subsidize this new manufacturing industry so as to put the new equipment within the reach of all who depend upon motor transport.

talk.start.para: - The trouble is that the Government cannot make up its mind.

speech.para: Air. BEASLEY. - It has no mind, and the further we go, the worse becomes the situation. The proposal of the right honorable member for Cowper that some financial assistance should be afforded to people who are prepared to install producer gas units is a good one, but nothing definite in that way has been done. The trouble is that what we hear from Ministers to-day may be cancelled by what they say to-morrow. No business man of this country would be prepared to take the word of the Minister for Supply and Development on any of the aspects of this important subject. The Minister would have to put his name on the dotted line for his word to carry weight. We expected a definite declaration from the honorable gentleman to-day, but he merely said that his "style was cramped ". The style of the public is cramped, and so is that of the motor traders and motor users, and of the thousands of men who look to the motor industry for their employment. It is high time that the Government crystallized its ideas on this subject. A definite policy should be announced without delay. However, it is probable that, at a not distant date, the Minister and his colleagues will be replaced by others who will make definite decisions on this subjest and others and give effect to them.

talk.start.para: . - There have been occasions when I have listened with a great deal of interest to speeches by the honorable member for West Sydney (Mr. Beasley), and have admired his clear thinking and capable exposition of ideas, but any such opinion that I may have had concerning the honorable member has been entirely changed by his speech on this subject. He said that the Government would not make up its mind on the subject, but I may well ask whether the honorable member himself has made up his mind. From time to time in this House he has stood as the champion of the unemployed, and, in speaking about the machinations of big business as it affected unemployment, has alleged that the big commercial interests of this country were particularly friendly to this Government. But on this occasion it is hard to tell where he stands. The honorable member said in one breath that we should not in any circumstances cause any additional unemployment, and in almost the next breath he said that for nine months the Government had done absolutely nothing in respect of petrol rationing. He remarked that it is now eleven months since war was declared and he went on to imply that petrol rationing should actually have been applied nine months ago. In these circumstances, I am entitled to ask the honorable member where he stands. Is he favorable to the preservation of normal employment in the petrol industry, or does he consider that rationing should have been enforced nine months ago? It seems to me that, in order to secure a political advantage, he is prepared to throw overboard his previous views on this subject.

speech.para: Looking at another aspect of the whole problem, I direct attention to the foreign exchange position, as presented to us by the honorable member. He said that the Government had sold our primary products to sterling countries, and implied that it should have sold them, not to the United Kingdom in order that thu people there might be saved from starvation or from the rationing of foodstuffs as it is enforced on the Continent of Europe, but to non-sterling countries. He would seem to advocate that we should have sold our primary products to Germany.

talk.start.para: - That is a lie.
-Order ! The use of the word "lie" is distinctly unparliamentary.

- At any rate, the honorable gentleman questioned the propriety of our selling our primary products to sterling countries. Does he imply that we should have sold them to Russia? .Surely not; he belongs to the non-Communist party! Does the honorable gentleman suggest that we should have sold our foodstuffs to Germany, Japan, or any other country in preference to the United Kingdom? Where is his clear thinking on this issue? He has accused the members of the Government of not thinking clearly, but he has lamentably failed to give us any indication that his own thinking is clear. Before he made any accusation against the Government in this connexion he should have set his own house in order.

speech.para: The right honorable member for Cowper (Sir Earle Page) referred to our lack of storage for petrol, but he is not altogether blameless on this count. This Government was in office for only a few months before war was declared. If responsibility must be placed upon any Government for our lack of petrol storage facilities, it must be placed upon the Government of which the right honorable member himself was an influential member for a number of years. It ill becomes him to whip this Government for the absence of storage facilities, for he was the Deputy Prime Minister of a Government which had ample opportunity to provide such facilities.

talk.start.para: - This Government did not carry out our plan.
- Noisy interjections must cease. The honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Harrison) is entitled to be heard in silence.

- When the Menzies Government assumed office just before the declaration of war it faced a very difficult situation. When the war occurred, it was given some small allotment in the foreign exchange pool. It then had to determine upon what commodities it would expend the sum allotted to it. Does the right honorable member for Cowper suggest that it should have spent its allotment exclusively on petrol? Does he suggest that the Government acted unwisely in using its money to buy a variety of necessary commodities? Surely he does not say that the whole of our foreign exchange resources should have been used to obtain petrol supplies.
- The Government of which I was a member laid its plans, but this Government did not give effect to them.

- The right honorable member cannot get away from the fact that, in spite of our increased petrol storage facilities, we have supplies sufficient to meet normal needs for only fourteen weeks. The Government of the United Kingdom has supplies available for eighteen months and the Government of Canada has supplies to meet its needs for two years.
- I still say that our plans were not put into operation. This Government gambled on the preservation of peace, and unfortunately war occurred.

- The right honorable member made some remarks concerning the number of tanks available. The Government knows that it could get tanks if it required them. In my opinion, the decision to develop our power alcohol industry will do something to solve the difficult problem that we are facing. At any rate, it will be more effective than the introduction of such fanciful ideas as asking people voluntarily to curtail their use of petrol. Some system of rationing is undoubtedly necessary. May I remind honorable members that the Sydney Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board some time ago made a request to the people of Sydney to curtail their use of water. The request was practically unheeded, with the result that the board has now found it necessary to introduce a continuous and drastic rationing system. In my opinion, it would be foolish to rely upon people to observe a voluntary rationing scheme. Compulsion is essential. Some modification should perhaps be made to the Government's scheme, 'but undoubtedly compulsion must be applied. The Minister for Supply and Development has told us that a scheme of petrol rationing has been in " cold storage " for some time. We all know why it has not been introduced. The honorable member for West Sydney suggested that all our unused resources - should be transferred to defence, and he added that there was still unemployment in the community. It may be necessary ultimately to transfer our resources, both used and unused, to the control of the defence authorities, but things must be done in their proper order and I do not think that the time has yet come for that action to be taken. We are all aware that many economic theories are being expounded, but surely no one would advocate the premature transfer of all of our resources to the defence and munition works. It would seem that the honorable member for West Sydney is of the opinion that the time for such a step had arrived nine months ago. I do not think so. We are all aware of the circumstances that are forcing the Government's hand at this moment. These are entirely apart from any consideration of the foreign exchange position. In my opinion, the time for rationing has come, though there is room for some difference of opinion as to the degree to which rationing should be applied. If the financial situation were the sole consideration of the Government at this moment I do not think that rationing would be enforced, but that is not the position. We are facing quite different possibilities.

speech.para: I wish to deal briefly, in the remaining few moments at my disposal, with one or two suggestions made by the right honorable member for Cowper. He said that the co-ordination of transport services was necessary. Such co-ordination is already in operation in our capital cities, but the right honorable member must realize that it is not possible to co-ordinate all transport services. For example, the delivery of fragile goods cannot be made at the same time as heavy loading, and by the same vehicles. Fragile and perishable commodities cannot be transported with tons of bitumen, balks of timber, and the like. Some perishable commodities would 'be utterly destroyed if they were loaded on vehicles containing certain other commodities. For this reason, transport can be co-ordinated only in a limited way, and where such co-ordination is possible, it is already being practised. The right honorable member referred to the possibility of increased unemployment in the transport industries. It is one thing to mention this important subject and quite another thing to pull down some bright and easy solution from the atmosphere. As I see it, the right honorable member's submissions in this connexion answer themselves. I know very we'll that there is a surplus of oil supplies in the world, and particularly in the United States of America. Oil is available there at probably a lower cost than ever before.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member has exhausted his time.

.- I desire to address myself briefly to the motion, particularly as petrol rationing affects a great number of persons in parts of the continent that have never yet seen a Minister or an Assistant Minister of the present Government. I refer to those who live far beyond the limits of our capital cities. I listened with interest to the Minister for Supply and Development (Sir Frederick Stewart) say that the Government was reluctant to introduce a scheme of petrol rationing. It is obvious that on the eve of an election the Government is hesitant to introduce any scheme which might incense the people. The Government knows very well that if it faced the people after having initiated a petrol rationing- scheme such as has been suggested, the people would rise up in their wrath and deal with it as it deserves to be dealt with. It is obvious that in this matter, behind the scenes, unseen and unheard, pressure is being brought to bear on the Government. The announcement of a scheme by the Minister for Supply and Development and the complete inability of the Government to make up its mind to implement or reject it have brought about chaos, not only in the motor industry itself, but also in other industries which depend for their existence on adequate supplies of petrol. The blundering on the part of the Government in connexion with this matter has left the people in a state of uncertainty. Almost immediately after the proposed rationing scheme was announced it was withdrawn following a public outcry, and steps were taken to delay a decision in regard to the matter. In the meantime the economic organization of the country and our war effort have been jeopardized. All the time the Government has its ear to the ground, endeavouring to find out what are the political reactions to its decisions. After the 7th September, however, when the people will have an opportunity to pass judgment on this Government, a very different state of affairs will prevail.

speech.para: Already the increased price of petrol has brought about a considerable diminution of- the demand. Those who formerly used their motor vehicles purely for pleasure now think twice before deciding on pleasure jaunts. The right honorable member for Cowper ('Sir Earle Page) has pointed out the disastrous effects that indiscriminate petrol rationing would have on the dairying industry. The Government should give very earnest consideration to the desirability of allowing liberal allocations of petrol to all primary producers. Any diminution of the supply of petrol to those engaged in the timber industry in the northern parts of the continent, and particularly in Queensland and Western Australia, where the timber industry is in a flourishing condition, will bring about widespread unemployment. We must also consider the effect of rationing on Australia's great pastoral industry and other important primary industries. Great difficulties will arise during the shearing season if the rationing scheme does not provide a reasonable allowance to shearers who are obliged to use motor transport in moving from station to station. To cite an example, in Queensland a gang of shearers may start shearing at, say, Logan Downs, near Claremont, proceeding from there to Carrondotta, near Cloncurry, 600 miles away, and finishing up at Charleville, 500 miles further south. In order to cover this large area, they are compelled to provide their own motor transport. It is customary for four or five shearers to share a car between them. Should any interruption of the normal procedure of shearers take place following petrol rationing, not only will the pastoral industry suffer through lack of shearers but also the earnings of shearers will be considerably reduced. Already there is a shortage of expert shearers because of enlistments in the Defence Forces. When dealing with the subject of the utilization of producer-gas units, the Minister for Supply and Development said that be had great hopes in that direction. His speech might aptly be labelled with the title of a song we hear so often these days, " Land of Hope' and Glory ". Among other things the honorable gentleman said that he hoped that the use of producer-gas units would be continued even after petrol rationing became no longer necessary.

But what has the Government done to make these units available to the public at a reasonable price? We know very well that in failing to do anything in that regard it is merely obeying the dictates of the oil combines. It is understood that the objective sought by the Government in the institution of a petrol rationing scheme is a reduction of the civil consumption by 33$ per cent. What has the Government done to foster the local production of motor spirit? The Assistant Minister (Mr. Fadden) is to be chairman of a committee to be set up to inquire into the possibility of expanding the production of power alcohol. Why has the Government delayed until now the institution of an inquiry into Australian sources of supply? On one of the first occasions on which I spoke after I first became a member of this House three years ago I urged the Government to do something to develop the power alcohol industry. We have been at war for eleven months and the Government has only now decided to appoint a committee to inquire into this matter. Earlier in the year in answer to a question, the Minister for Supply and Development informed me that he had been in consultation with representatives of the cane-growers in Queensland regarding the manufacture of power alcohol.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member has exhausted his time.

.- The speech made by the honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Harrison) was what might he expected from one whose national vision extends around the shores of Rose Bay, and is bounded on the east by Bondi and probably on the west by King's Cross. The honorable member lauded the Government and praises the Minister for Supply and Development (Sir Frederick Stewart) for having procrastinated in regard to this matter ever since the outbreak of war. He said that the Government deserves great praise for having done nothing until the situation became so bad that it was compelled to do something. I suggest that if the honorable member for his livelihood were dependent upon the foresight of the Government for the means of getting to and from market, or to and from his farm to the nearest town some distance away - he would not be praising the Government quite so lavishly to-day. The honorable member is so fortunately situated that if a petrol rationing scheme were to be brought into operation to-morrow he could jump into the nearest 'bus, tram or train and be transported to the city or to his place of business without delay. If any of his constituents live more than five or ten minutes walk from a tram-stop, they probably write a complaint to their State member about it. The position of those who reside in country areas is very much different. Any scheme of petrol rationing must envisage the difficulties not only of those living in country areas but also of those whose livelihood depends on the use of motor transport. I think I can claim to have exhibited some degree of foresight in this matter because in May or June of last year, before the outbreak of the war, I directed a question to the Minister for Supply and Development suggesting that in view of the possibility of war and of petrol restrictions being imposed, some effort should be made by the Government to subsidize the manufacture of producer gas units. I pointed out to the honorable gentleman that although they provided an alternative means of fuel conservation these units were too costly for the man on the land to buy. Since then, however, practically nothing has been done to encourage the manufacture of cheap producer gas units. Every advantage should have been taken of the opportunity to utilize our vast charcoal resources. This phase' of our war problem should have been foreseen when the war broke out. It was contemplated by many, but their warnings were not heeded by the Government. I regard the encouragement of the manufacture of cheap charcoal and gas producer units as a very definite part of the Government's responsibility. To encourage the use of such units in this country we must first have adequate supplies of charcoal distributed throughout the length and breadth of the land. What has the Government done to ensure that? The State governments have taken some action but, so far as I know, nothing has been done by the Commonwealth.
- The State governments are acting as the agents of the Commonwealth.

- -I inspected producer gas units with a view to purchasing one for my own use, but I have not bought one because charcoal supplies are not available in my district. Although thousands of gallons of petrol are used daily in the northern districts of New South Wales, no charcoal depots have been established north of Newcastle. I would willingly install a producer gas unit in my motor truck if I could obtain fuel for it.

speech.para: The subject of employment, which the honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Harrison) mentioned, is a vital one. But there could be no better way of ensuring continuity of employment for men thrown out of work because of petrol rationing than to encourage the use of producer gas units. Thousands of unskilled men could be engaged in the production of fuel charcoal at a reasonable cost.

Another obstacle to the general use of these units is their high cost, which at present is beyond the purse of the ordinary individual. In making its plans for the manufacture of Australian motor cars by one company, the Government was careful to ensure that the vehicles could be produced at a low cost. On the other hand, it is allowing every small manufacturer to make producer gas units, with the result that few of them will be able to increase the volume of their production sufficiently to bring about a reduction of the cost of individual units. Since the Government has shown such concern for the economic production of an Australian motor car, it should be equally solicitous for the economic production of producer gas units, whose use will help the nation to conserve petrol supplies.

So far as I am aware, the only oil fuel depots in New South Wales are at Newcastle, Sydney and Port Kembla; the whole of the north coast area is cut off from fuel supplies and we should be in a sorry plight if the north were invaded. The Government should encourage every private individual to purchase 40 gallon or 80 gallon drums of petrol if it really believes that additional fuel storage is required. Unfortunately, those people who had the foresight to store large supplies of petrol are threatened that any quantity above what may be permitted under a rationing scheme may be requisitioned. The Government has been inconsistent in this matter. It has changed its tune so often that the public is too confused to know why rationing is necessary. I believe that petrol should be rationed to a degree and I commend the right honorable member for Cowper for having raised this issue, although I do not necessarily agree with all of his suggestions. I sincerely hope that the board to which the Minister for Supply and Development referred will make recommendations that will be more acceptable ' than those first brought forward.

talk.start.para: .- Members of the Australian Labour party - non-Communist support the proposals of the right honorable member for Cowper (Sir Earle Page) ; a scheme to avoid the Government's drastic proposals for petrol rationing is long overdue. It is not unusual, when motions of this kind are under discussion, to hear the Government damned with faint praise, but to-day it has been praised with faint damns, even by its most ardent and slavish advocates, such as the honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Harrison). The arguments of that honorable gentleman centred on the contentions of the honorable member for West Sydney (Mr. Beasley). He is either abysmally ignorant of the principles of relevant argument, or he wittingly put up a tawdry defence of the incompetence of the Minister for Supply and Development. The honorable member for West Sydney said that, as the result of contracts made by the Government, Australia had sold the major portion of its primary products to countries which pay in sterling, whereas the countries from which it bought its petrol supplies were non-sterling countries. The honorable gentleman then rightly adduced the argument that a government with any business acumen must have foreseen that one or both of two things could happen as a result of the war. It was almost certain that there would be a difficulty in finding the foreign exchange required for our purchases of petrol, or there would be a shortage of tanker transport due to enemy action. Neither of these two things was taken into account by the Government, which should have introduced rationing on a small scale at the beginning of the Avar in a way that would have caused inconvenience to no one.

The Gold Mining Encouragement Act 1.940, was assented to on the 4th June, and regulations designed to give effect to the provisions of that act were made on the 17th July. The purpose of the amending bill is to remove certain drafting defects in the original act, and to make other adjustments of a minor character which are considered advisable in the light of advice offered by mining experts, whose assistance the Commonwealth invited and obtained during the drafting of the regulations. The proposed amendments are four in number - (a) Section 7(1) relating to refunds to prospectors, is being amended to remove an ambiguity in the existing wording of that section as regards " fine gold ". (6) Section 10(l)a is to be amended to alter the basis of determining the cost of mining and treating ore.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Section 10(1) c requires amend ment to correct a drafting error in fixing the maximum allowance of £2 an ounce of fine gold for development.

item.label: (d)
item.para: New section 10a to give a dis cretion to the Commissioner of Taxation to adopt a variation of the quarterly period, as defined in the act, for the making of applications for refunds. Section 7(1) of the principal act, which relates to refunds of gold tax to bona fide prospectors, provides that -

quote.para: The Commonwealth eha.ll, subject to the regulations, refund to a person who is u bona fide prospector the amount of tax upon the first twenty-five ounces of gold upon which he directly or indirectly pays tax in any year.

speech.para: It is proposed to insert the word " fine " before the word " gold " in this subsection, in order to remove an ambiguity inherent in the existing wording. The intention of the section is that a refund shall be made of the amount of tax on 25 ounces of fine gold, and not on 25 ounces of gold, as expressed in the subsection.

The present provision in section 10(l)a relates the cost of production to average cost of gold production in the quarter during which the gold is produced. The difficulty with this is that the ore, from which that gold is produced, is not itself necessarily mined in the same quarter. It sometimes happens that no actual ore is mined during a quarter, even though the ore, previously mined, is treated during the quarter. The Commissioner of Taxation is convinced, as the result of advice tendered by gold-mining experts and Mines Department officials in the various States, that the present provision is inequitable, and should be altered so that the cost of production shall have reference to the cost of the actual ore treated.

A drafting correction is necessary in section 10 (a) c in order to ensure that the maximum amount to be taken into account as the average cost of development shall in no ease exceed the sum of £2. This was the definite intention set out in the second-reading speech on the original bill, but the existing provisions fail to give proper effect to that intention.

In connexion with new section 10a, mining experts consider that a fixed quarter is not a convenient period for all producers in the industry. Books, statistics and records are, in some cases, kept either on a weekly or four-weekly basis. The proposal is that the act be altered to provide for variation of the period of a " quarter ". A new section is being inserted so as to give discretion to the Commissioner of Taxation in determining the exact period, on an application from a producer.

quote.para: That it is expedient that an appropriation of revenue be made for the purposes of a bill for an ant to provide for the payment of a bounty on the production of raw cotton.
That Mr. Spender and Mr. Fadden do prepare and bring in a hill to carry out the foregoing resolution.

debate.para: Bill brought up by Mr. Spender, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: . - I move - That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The bill provides for the payment of bounty on raw cotton produced during the years 1941 to 1945 inclusive. The basic rates of bounty for each successive year will be 4 3/4d., 4£d., 4£d., 4d. and 3£d. per lb. respectively, when the Liverpool spot price of American middling raw cotton is 6d. per lb. As the Liverpool price varies up or down from 6d. per lb., each basic rate of bounty will be reduced or increased by an equivalent amount, except that in no circumstances will the bounty be allowed to exceed 5£d. per lb. The bill also provides that the basic rate of bounty, and, therefore, all adjustments thereof in accordance with fluctuations of the Liverpool price, will be reduced at any time to the extent that any customs duty may be imposed on imported raw cotton.

As it is possible that the Liverpool Cotton Exchange may close during the war, the bill enables the Minister to use the New York spot price of American middling raw cotton, and other factors, as a basis for determining an equivalent Liverpool price, so that Australian cotton growers may receive equitable rates of bounty.

An annual sum of £150,000 will be provided from Consolidated Revenue for paying the bounty, and, as usual, the unexpended balance in any year will be available for bounty in any future year under the act, in addition to the £150,000 provided for that year.
Other provisions in the bill merely give the usual powers which are essential to the efficient administration of the bounty, and the safeguarding of the interests of the Commonwealth.

Existing raw cotton bounty legislation will expire on the 30th November next with the completion of the harvesting and ginning of the 1940 cotton crop in Queensland. Early adoption by Parliament of the present bill is essential, in view of the great need for substantially increasing local cotton production for war-time needs. These needs apply particularly to summer uniforms, and various items of equipment, including tents, canvas, &c, for all the fighting services, and the manufacture of certain high explosives. Australia's raw cotton requirements have advanced from 35,000 bales for the yea)1 ended on the 30th June, 1940, to at least 65,000 bales for the coming year. The 1940 Queensland crop will produce only S,000 bales. Were it to remain at 8,000 bales, much of the balance of 57,000 bales would have to be imported from the United States of America, involving a serious drain upon the Empire's sterling funds in that country.

Largely increased production of raw cotton in Australia would permit of a considerable reduction of American imports, as both countries produce similar kinds of raw cotton. Hence, more of our foreign exchange resources would be available for the purchase of aeroplanes, machine tools, and other American commodities of great importance to Australia's war effort.

A marked expansion of local cotton production will require considerable organization by the Queensland Government and its Cotton Board, and also much preparatory work by present and prospective cotton-growers in clearing many thousands of acres in light-timbered country, and preparing the land for planting by next October. This expensive work could not very well be undertaken without the security assured to growers by Parliament's early approval of the bill.

The present legislation arises mainly from an exhaustive investigation of the industry made by the Tariff Board, the results of which are contained in its report of the 3rd April, 1939. In that report the Tariff Board drew attention to various unsatisfactory phases of the industry which had combined to cause the average yield an acre to fall to a very low level, now much below the yields in many other countries.

The board found that Queensland climatic conditions were too variable and prone to dry periods to enable reasonably good yields to be obtained, and it suggested the obvious solution of growing cotton under irrigation, as has been done with great success in certain other countries. Cotton yields in Egypt, certain American States, Peru and Russia, where irrigation is utilized, are from three to four times as high as in Queensland, and the crops never fail.

The Tariff Board also reported adversely on the efficiency of the industry in regard to cultural and rotation practices, weed control, and the selection and breeding of varieties which will resist pests, disease, and dry weather. Failing substantial improvement, the cost to the Commonwealth of making cottongrowing attractive would become too heavy a burden on the community to be economically justified. At the same time, the board declared that the presence of a cotton-growing industry in Australia was a form of insurance that, in times of emergency such as the present war, a considerable quantity of cotton would be available to Australia.

It was not possible last year for the Government, with its manifold activities in organizing the effective prosecution of Australia's war effort, to give adequate consideration to a suitable long-term cotton policy which would solve the difficult problems mentioned by the Tariff Board. The Government had to be content to renew the bounty for a period of one year at a basic rate of 4£d. per lb., which was Id. per lb. higher than the rate recommended by the Tariff Board. It was granted for the purpose of encouraging an increase of production for urgent war needs, .and also to meet undoubted increases of the cost of raw cotton production brought about by the war.

A few months ago, however, the Government was able to complete negotiations with the Queensland Government for satisfactory measures to cope with the problems noted by the Tariff Board. The Queen.=land Government has definitely undertaken, in writing, that its plans for improving the efficiency of the cotton-growing industry will pre eminently, and almost exclusively, provide for -

item.label: (a)
item.para: the quickest possible conversion of cotton production from dry farming to irrigation by the most economic means for each selected locality;

item.label: (b)
item.para: a special campaign by enough thoroughly qualified men to instruct all farmers personally and quickly as to the absolute need for practising correct rotations and other essential cultural methods; such campaign to be followed up persistently with the object of ensuring that the best practices shall be adopted by the bulk of the farmers in the shortest possible time. This campaign will include the circulation of suitable literature;

item.label: (c)
item.para: a substantial increase, in quality and number, of the personnel of the Cotton Research Section, for the specific purpose of accelerating vital scientific work on plant-breeding, pests, diseases, soils, fertilizers, cultural practices, and especially the new problems that are sure to be encountered with production under irrigation;

item.label: (d)
item.para: anything related to these measures. The ultimate cost to the Queensland

speech.para: Government of fully implementing these undertakings will be at least £650,000. That government has also agreed to ensure complete co-operation between its Department of Agriculture, the Queensland Cotton Board, cottonspinners and the Department of Trade and Customs on all relevant matters, particularly in regard to the supply at all times of the types of raw cotton needed by Australian users. A fully representative committee will be appointed soon to advise both governments on these matters.

As evidence of the Queensland Government's recognition of the economic burden, and the grave risk of continuing to produce raw cotton in Australia wholly under dry-farming conditions, and of its good faith in relation to the undertakings to which I have referred, I mention that that government provided £65,126 during the financial year 1939-40 for loans to cotton farmers and scientific research, including £21,500 for irrigation works and experiments, and will provide a much larger sum for similar work during 1940-41. In addition, the Premier of Queensland has signified his government's intention to proceed with plans for the exploitation of underground water supplies, the provision of finance for individual pumping schemes, and for the construction of an additional irrigation weir on the Dawson River north of the town of Theodore. The Queensland Government has already inaugurated a scheme to ensure the adoption by cotton farmers of the best cultural methods, and the personnel of the Queensland Cotton Research Station is being augmented for the specific purpose of facilitating work on plant breeding and the control of pests. A special soils officer from the Waite Institute at Adelaide is at present actively engaged in the Callide and Theodore areas on the location of soils most suitable for cotton production. The Commonwealth Council for Scientific and Industrial Research will assist in locating better rainfall areas.

The Premier of Queensland has advised the Prime Minister that his Government is endeavouring in- every possible way to improve and intensify the cotton yield, in order to develop an important Australian primary industry, with consequential benefits in the reduction of overseas purchases, and the maintenance of adequate supplies for Australian manufacturers.

In view of these arrangements, the Government has brought down the present bill, which provides for gradually reducing rates of bounty during the next five years. The basic rate for the first year (1941) will be 4|d. per lb., as against the present basic rate of 4¼d per lb. The increase of id. per lb. is considered essential, partly in order to cover further probable increases of production costs due to the war, and to machinery, pipes and water for irrigation, but mainly in order to encourage a marked increase of production by making the industry reasonably attractive to farmers.

After 1941, the basic bounty will fall by id. per lb. each year until 1945, when the basic bounty will be £d. per lb. less than for the 1944 season. These reductions of bounty are designed to meet the ifr. Spender. gradually lower costs of production which must flow from the steadily increasing degree of production under irrigation.

It should be noted that the basic rates of bounty mentioned by me are related to a Liverpool price of 6d. per lb., and that they vary up or down as the Liverpool price varies from that figure. Since the war began the Liverpool price has always been higher than 6d. per lb., and is now 7.95d. per lb. If the lastnamed Liverpool price should be maintained throughout the 19.41 period of production, the basic rate of bounty for that year of 4£d. per lb. would produce an actual rate of 2.8d. per lb., which would cover a total production of 25,700 hales of raw cotton under the annual appropriation of £150,000. This quantity is 8,000 bales more than Australia's record output. If the 1941 production should be less than '25,700 bales, the corresponding saving of bounty would be carried forward to any future year in addition to the regular provision of £150,000 for that year. Moreover, a large increase of production will reduce ginning costs per pound, and thus further benefit cotton-growers.

In the cotton-growing industry there are now approximately 2,700 growers, 1,000 field workers and 2,000 cottonpickers. The ginneries employ 170 persons, the total number directly employed thus being 5,870. Advices just to hand from Queensland indicate that possibly 80,000 acres will be planted to cotton in Queensland for next year's crop, as against only 38,000 acres for the 1940 season. If this estimate should be realized, cotton-growers will have rendered good service to the Commonwealth in connexion with its war effort.

It is worth while remembering that the cotton industry in all its phases is the largest individual industry in the world, and that, under conditions of the highest efficiency, this industry - in both the primary and the secondary branches - has every chance of becoming one of the largest in the Commonwealth. When cotton-growing has been converted almost wholly to production under irrigation, the cost of producing raw cotton in Australia will become substantially lower than it has ever been, and this will enable the industry to be continued on a much larger scale at lower rates of bounty or, alternatively, with tariff protection. Incidentally, a great expansion of cottongrowing will create opportunities for other farmers who may, through stress of war or shrinkage of exports of their present products, find it necessary to seek another vocation.

Finally, the bill constitutes a cooperative effort by the Commonwealth and the Queensland Governments to raise the cotton-growing industry to a level of efficiency not nearly approached previously in -this country. Both Governments are sharing the necessary expenditure to this end. If this joint policy succeeds - and there is no reason why it should not do so - the total number of farmers and workers now engaged in the industry will be greatly increased, and Australia will be far less reliant upon overseas sources of supply than it is at the present time. I strongly commend the bill to this House.
