talker.role: Minister without portfolio assisting the Treasurer
talker.name: FADDEN, Arthur William
Mr FADDEN

talk.start.para: . - When this measure was previously before the House, the debate was adjourned in order to enable the provisions of the bill to be considered, and in order to afford to those interested an opportunity to make representations to the Government for the improvement or modification of the bill.

speech.para: In the intervening period, full advantage has been taken of the opportunity, and a large number of representations has 'been received and considered. They fall principally within two categories - those from prospective taxpayers who have sought amendment of the bill in order to remove or reduce their own liability, and those from representative bodies and taxation experts who have made valuable suggestions in relation to the drafting and operation of the bill.

All of the representations have 'been carefully considered on their merits. As a result, it is proposed, when the hill reaches the committee stage, to submit certain amendments. A memorandum setting out these amendments, with a short explanation of each, will be circulated to honorable members for their information.

I shall refer to the principal matters dealt with by the amendments. Provision is made in the bill for the appointment of a Board of Referees to deal with certain matters. It is relevant to point out that this hoard is not in any sense an appeal board. Under the bill, appeals from assessments of the Commissioner of Taxation will go either to the High Court or to the present Taxation Board of Review. The proposed Board of Referees will discharge different functions. It will exercise discretionary powers in relation to prescribed matters. These relate to concessions and not to the interpretation of the law. Under the bill, the board has power to recommend to the Minister that a higher statutory percentage than that prescribed by the bill should be allowed in respect of any class of business in which there is " an exceptional degree of risk". Upon examination, these words have been found to be too limited in scope. It is proposed, therefore, to alter the wording in order to enable the Board to recommend a higher statutory percentage to be applied to any class of business with which is associated some " unavoidable condition " which makes it just that a higher statutory percentage deduction should be allowed.

talk.start.para: - What is meant by " unavoidable condition " ?

- That will be for the board to decide. There are such conditions as a series of droughts preceding a good year, and certain conditions associated with the mining industry. This alteration will allow consideration to be given, not only to cases where there is an exceptional degree of risk of loss, but also to other kinds of cases, such as those in which there are wasting assets. It is proposed also to amend the bill in order to permit the Board of Referees to grant a higher percentage standard to a company within a class where the profits of an accounting period relate to a period greater than that accounting period.

speech.para: The Board of Referees has power alao to allow to a company a greater amount of capital than that calculated under the provisions of the hill. Doubt has 'been expressed in some quarters as to whether the board would be limited in its determination to the methods of computation of capital set out in the bill. This was not the intention, and a simple amendment is proposed to allay these fears, and to make it clear that the 'board is at liberty to determine the true capital employed in Australia, irrespective of the provisions which bind the Commissioner in his computation of capital.

Another important matter dealt with in the amendments relates to the adjustment of the capital computation in respect of non-purchased assets. Under the bill it was proposed that where such an asset appeared in the books of a company at the outbreak of war, viz., the 3rd September, 1939, the value then ascribed to the asset should be adopted for purposes of the computation; and that, where such an asset was created or acquired after that date, it should be taken into account at its value at the date of creation or acquisition. This provision has caused more controversy than any other. Although its inclusion in the bill was a genuine attempt to deal equitably with assets of this nature, a further consideration of the matter, in the light of a wealth of expert opinion which has been made available, has led to the conclusion that it would be unwise to retain the provision.

Although it was thought, when the bill was drafted, that it would not be unfair to take companies at their own valuation with regard to assets created or acquired before the 3rd September, 1939, the fact is that much discontent has been evinced by companies affected, because lone which had adopted a conservative policy in relation to the writing down of assets would be worse treated than one which had permitted them to remain in the accounts at a higher value. It has been suggested, that, if the provision remains, it will be exploited by companies which will now write into their books large amounts of goodwill and other similar assets, greatly reducing or removing their liability for the tax.

The consensus of informed and unbiassed opinion on the subject is that the only way to prevent evasion in this connexion, and to place companies affected by the tax on a basis of parity, is to allow nothing at all, in the computation of capital, in respect of non-purchased assets of the nature of goodwill, trademarks, copy-rights, &c.

The matter of dividends paid by one company to another has had to be considered. It has been alleged that to tax profits of an operating company, and then to include dividends paid out of those profits, in the taxable profit of a recipient company would amount to double taxation, and a variety of devices to avoid this has been suggested. After consideration of all of these, an amendment is proposed to delete altogether from the taxable profit of a company any dividend that it receives from another company. Thus profits will be decided to be taxable or non-taxable in the hands of the company which makes them, and will not be followed into the hands of any other company which may receive part of them in the form of dividends. A consequential amendment will be the exclusion from capital of the amount invested in the shares.

Prom some quarters, the request has been received that, with regard to the deduction of State taxes, the basis of allowing taxes paid should be departed from, and taxes payable should be substituted. It should be pointed out that one of the things most keenly sought in the drafting of the bill was to adhere as closely as possible to the taxable income, for income tax purposes, for the ascertainment of liability under this law. This has such obvious advantages, both to the taxpayers in the checking of their assessments and to the department in simplicity of administration, and, therefore, the reduction of the costs of collection, that it need hardly be stressed. While State taxes paid in the accounting period are the criterion for income tax purposes, the Government would be most reluctant to prescribe any other basis for the purposes of this tax. It must also be remembered that what would suit one company in this respect would not suit another. The income tax law at one time permitted a company to elect whether it would have a deduction of taxes paid or taxes payable in arriving at the distributable income. An almost negligible percentage elected for taxes payable, the large majority preferring to have the deduction of taxes paid, this being a fixed, certain and unvariable amount which, over a period of years, arrived at the same result as the allowances of taxes payable. After considerable discussion, it has been decided to provide for the deduction of State taxes payable only in the first accounting period of a company formed after the 1st July, 1939; otherwise, such a company would obtain no deduction in respect of State taxes. After its first year, such a company, in common with all other companies, will be entitled to the deduction of taxes paid.

Difficulties have been encountered in connexion with life assurance companies. Those that are purely mutual have no paid-up capital or shareholders' funds in the ordinary sense; in their case policyholders' funds are the nearest approach to shareholders' funds. It would have been possible to introduce a rather complicated provision to treat such funds as capital, but, as the Government is convinced that these societies do not make on these funds profits equal to the statutory percentage, and that the result would have been to render them non-taxable, the straightforward course of exempting them from the tax has been adopted. It may be mentioned that the War-Time Profits Tax Assessment Act 1917-18 similarly exempted these societies.

Another point arises in the computation of the capital of a life assurance company which is not wholly mutual. It is not proposed to exempt these companies. For income tax purposes, they are allowed a deduction of four per centum of the actuarial value of their liabilities. Where the amount of liabilities, as calculated in the accounts of the company, exceeds the amount upon which the income tax deduction is based, it is proposed to treat the excess as accumulated profits and, therefore, as capital, in accordance with the general scheme of the bill.

While on the subject of insurance, inference may be made to another proposed amendment. This relates to insurance business other than life assurance. Many companies carrying on business in Australia re-insure risks with companies outside

Australia. The income tax law provides that they shall not be allowed any deduction in respect of the premiums that they have to pay to the absentee companies for this re-insurance. Thus, in effect, their taxable income includes, not only their own profit, but also the profits made on the business by the absentee companies with which they re-insure. The Government has recognized that it would be unfair to relate the total taxable income to the capital of the local company, as the percentage would be inflated by the inclusion in the taxable income of the reinsurance premiums paid out. It has, therefore, been decided to remedy this position by providing for a pro rata increase of the capital.

Clause 21 of the bill deals with the computation of capital. It has been re-arranged for greater clarity, and to enable a more speedy understanding of its import to be reached. In addition, other matters have been provided for: -

Reserves created out of the issue of shares at a premium are to be treated as capital. They are, in fact, in the nature of capital, and the purpose of the amendment is merely to make it clear that they are to be so treated.

The provision to reduce capital employed, by the amount of a profit and loss debit, has been deleted. While this process would be correct in the technical ascertainment of capital, the Government is now satisfied that it would cause hardship if the amount upon which the statutory percentage deduction is to be calculated were to be reduced by the amount of temporary trading losses which will have to be made good out of future profits.

An amendment is also to be made to ensure that capital invested in assets which have been thrown out of production a3 the result of war or other causes shall not be excluded in the computation of capital.

Where a company receives a premium in respect of a lease, the whole of the premium comes into its taxable income and thus into its taxable profit. This will naturally result in a high percentage to capital. An amendment is proposed to apply to the taxable profit a rate approximate to a spreading of the premium over the period of the lease. This follows the principle of the income tax.

These represent the principal amendments which the Government proposes to make. There are others of less importance to which no particular reference need he made at this stage but which will, of course, come up for the consideration of honorable members when the bill is in committee.

Needless to say, there' have been many representations which the Government has been unable to approve. These vary from those that suggest that the bill should be widened in its scope, to those that suggest that it should be further limited.

It has been alleged that small companies will be taxed while large companies will escape. As a general statement, this is not borne out by departmental investigations. Any company, large or small, will be liable to the tax if it makes more than the statutory percentage on its capital, and will be free from the tax if it makes less. It is unreasonable for critics to select certain companies of large capital and arrive at the conclusion, on their own calculations, that such companies will not be liable for the tax, and that therefore the tax is unsound. These critics, of course, have no information as to what is the taxable income of such companies, as distinct from their published profits, or what would be the capital they employ as distinct from their published figures. The basis of the tax was fully explained by the Treasurer in his speech introducing the bill, and need not be recapitulated. Et is obvious that there will be companies, both large and small, which will not be liable for the very reason that they do not make more than the statutory percentage upon their capital. The tax does not purport to be a tax upon all companies; therefore, nothing is proved by showing that certain companies will not be liable.

It has been asserted in certain quarters that it is wrong to treat as capital for the purpose of this tax, the reserves and accumulated profits of a company. Unfortunately, these assertions have not been supported by any logical reasoning.

There is nothing in the underlying idea of the tax which would justify the limitation of the statutory percentage to paidup capital. The idea is to base the deduc- tion upon the funds which the shareholders have at stake.

Paid-up capital may be broadly referred to as the money which the shareholders originally contributed. Accumulated profits and reserves represent amounts which, instead of being withdrawn and utilized in personal expenditure or other investments, are permitted to remain, or, in effect, to be re-invested in the company. They are just as much entitled to be treated as capital, for the purposes of this tax, as if they had been distributed and further capital had been issued or called up to the amount of the distributions. 'Where shareholders have permitted profits to be retained in the business, to ensure its financial stability -a policy which cannot be criticized - it would be most unfair to deprive them of the statutory percentage deduction in respect of these accumulations.

It has to be borne in mind that what are described as large companies usually have their shareholdings widely spread over the community, whilst small companies often represent merely the incorporation of certain activities of one or more wealthy men. It would be most misleading to gauge the special ability of a company to bear a war-time tax merely by reference to the amount of its profit. Regard must be had to its ability to pay special taxation and still distribute to its shareholders a reasonable dividend upon their invested capital.

There seems to be some misconception regarding the computation of capital where companies have issued bonus shares or have created reserves by the writing up of the value of assets. Honorable members may be sure that the bill adequately prevents the inflation of capital by such methods. It is questionable whether bonus shares so issued could be regarded as " capital paid up in money or other valuable consideration." The bill does not leave this matter to conjecture. It prescribes the value at which assets shall be taken into account in the computation of capital, and where assets appear in the books of a company at values in excess of the prescribed value, the amount of the excess is deducted from capital. The amendment proposed in respect of non-purchased assets in the nature of goodwill further tightens up this aspect of the matter, for it is proposed to attribute no value at all to these assets in the computation of capital, whatever value may be attributed to them in the books of the company.

It has been urged in some quarters that private companies should be excluded from the operation of the tax on the ground that they are already sufficiently heavily taxed. Whatever argument may have existed in favour of this view fails, because of the amendment of the Income Tax Assessment Act this year which imposed a tax upon the undistributed income of public companies. The Commissioner of Taxation has stated that, by the imposition of this tax, the majority of public companies will have to pay more tax upon their undistributed income than they would pay if their liability were ascertained in accordance with the provisions of the law which apply to the undistributed income of private companies.

It is further alleged that the high rate of profits made by private companies is due largely to the exceptional ability and energy which their proprietors display in the conduct of their business and that, to the extent that it is due to these factors, the company should be relieved from special taxation. This argument cannot be accepted. Everywhere, the product of ability and energy is subjected to specially heavy taxation. If a man can make only £250 a year, he pays no federal income tax at the present time. If he makes £500 he pays relatively little; but if by the exercise of exceptional ability and energy he can make £2,000 he pays income taxes, Federal and State, out of all proportion to the amounts, if any, paid by those able only to make smaller incomes. It has been claimed that the tax should be applied to .individuals and partnerships as well as to companies. The Treasurer in his financial statement, delivered on the 2nd May, stated the reason why the tax is confined to companies. In seeking for the sources from which money for war-time expenditure should be obtained, the Government sought to strike a fair balance between individuals and companies. By an increase of the graduated rates, individuals are to be called upon to pay considerably increased income tax for the current financial year. As was explained by the Treasurer in his financial statement, it was necessary to obtain further taxes from companies. This could have been done, in a somewhat unscientific, although easy, manner, simply by increasing the flat rate of tax upon the taxable income of all companies. In preference to this, the Government decided to obtain the amount which seemed, at the time, to be required from companies by the undistributed profits tax, which applies only to public companies, and the war-time (company) tax which applies alike to public and private companies. For a proper appreciation of the matter, therefore, it is necessary to recognize that this tax is merely one of the forms chosen to obtain from companies what, in any case, it had been decided to obtain from them in some form or another. From this angle there would be no justification for the extension of the tax, at the present time, to individuals or partnerships. What the future may hold, in this regard it is at present impossible to say. It has to be borne in mind that an individual, whether deriving his income from a partnership or not, has to pay income tax at the graduated rates applicable to the whole of his income and is unable, as is a company, to have a portion of his income relieved from the graduation and assessed at a flat rate. It has been urged that the statutory percentage deduction should be extended to any capital which plays any part in the production of the taxable profit, whether that capital is employed in Australia or not. It must be said at once that this would cause a considerable reduction of the estimated revenue from the tax and would possibly necessitate a revision of the rates of tax in order to produce the required amount. To that degree, it would operate to the detriment of companies which employ the whole of their capital in Australia. The Government has decided not to accede to this request. It sees no reason why, for instance, a company should be allowed a deduction in respect of capital invested in head-office premises in London or New York, which in all probability it would have if it carried on no business at all in Australia. To the degree to which a company employs its capital in Australia, with the benefits which arise to the community from that employment, the deduction will be allowed.

It is desirable to make some reference to the position of mining companies under this bill. Gold-mining is exempt from income tax, and as companies engaged in that industry have no taxable income they consequently have no taxable profit for the purpose of this tax. They are, however, subjected to special taxation under the Gold Tax Act. Leading representatives of the mining industry as a whole have been at pains to assure the Government that they desire no special treatment under the bill; but on the other hand are prepared to bear their share of the tax in common with other sections of industry. Representations have been made, however, on behalf of individual mining companies asking, as a maximum, for the complete exemption of all mining companies from the tax. The Government is unable to accede to this request, particularly in view of the attitude of the industry generally, as I have already mentioned. It is to be remembered that the Income Tax Assessment Act allows deductions in respect of expenditure upon plant and development of the mining property and that the taxable income, and taxable profit, for this tax are arrived at after the allowance of these deductions. There is no doubt that this completely meets the position with regard to the large majority of mining companies and obviates the necessity for any special treatment in this bill except as may be available to companies generally. Consideration of the individual cases mentioned has, however, revealed that the provision in the Income Tax Assessment Act does not, in all cases, work satisfactorily to allow a recoupment of capital expenditure upon plant and development over the life of the mine. It is, however, thought that this is not a matter for adjustment in this bill, and consideration is being given to an amendment of the Income Tax Assessment Act in order to extend the deduction in respect of plant and development. Companies carrying on mining businesses will be able to apply to the Board of Referees for an increased statutory percentage. While it is not possible to anticipate what the board might do with such an application, it is obvious that those companies on whose behalf special representations have been made have taken the pessimistic view that no such higher percentage would be awarded to the mining industry.

The matters to which I have referred represent the main features in connexion with which representations have been made to the Government. There have been others relating to individual cases and to alteration of the verbiage of the bill, to which it is unnecessary to make detailed reference at this stage. From what I have said and the explanatory memorandum which will be available to honorable members, they will be able to obtain an understanding of the intentions of the Government with regard to the bill.

talk.start.para: .- The Opposition agrees with the principle of company taxation, and consequently intends to support the second reading of the bill, although some of my colleagues will doubtless have a good deal to say concerning certain provisions during the committee stage. The object of the measure is to extract from companies a portion of the additional revenue required to meet our war expenditure. It cannot be said that this is a popular measure, as it has, as the Assistant Treasurer (Mr. Fadden) admitted, met with a good deal of criticism. The Government has received representations from various sections of the community, and when the proposed amendments have been moved honorable members will be in a better position to debate the bill. At present we are at a disadvantage, because we have not before us the specific amendments to which the Assistant Treasurer referred, but I feel sure that the measure will be criticized somewhat severely by the representatives of small companies with respect to the incidence of the tax. A leading financial writer in Australia dealt with the measure in the following terms-
- Whom does the honorable member propose to cite?
- I propose to read a portion of an article which appeared in the Brisbane Courier-Mail on the 23rd July of this year. The writer stated -

quote.para: The Federal Government will meet with considerable criticism if, in the bill now before Parliament, it intends to proceed with the proposed tax on all profits over 8 per cent.
In its present form the tax will not reach some of Australia's 'biggest and wealthiest companies.
An analysis of the latest profits of 60 major companies shows that only fifteen, or a quarter of them, will come within its scope.
Many companies, leaders in their particular industry, employing millions of pounds in their business, and whose names are household words, are among those which apparently will be missed.

speech.para: The measure has been criticized largely on the ground that large companies will not be Drought within the scope of this measure, and, if I understood the Assistant Treasurer correctly, he endeavoured to make a number of excuses for large companies not being brought within the ambit of the bill.

talk.start.para: - I gave reasons and not excuses.

- I suppose that they have been excluded because they have been, able to use their influence with the Government. The measure has been roundly condemned by various income tax experts. It is unnecessary for me to mention the names of many large companies, some of which are well known in Australia, which will not be affected by this legislation. There is a general conviction among those to be affected by the taxes to be imposed under this measure that to tax profits on the basis of the capital employed is entirely wrong. Numerous complaints have been made by the representatives of small companies, and I trust that when the measure is in committee the Treasurer will accept amendments which will meet some of the complaints. It has been contended with a good deal of force that a badly managed company in -which a large amount of capital is employed may not show any profits, whereas a small company in which a small amount of capital is employed may be managed with such ability and care that it can show huge profits. It has been contended that this measure is a deliberate attempt to injure small companies in which a small amount of capital is employed; to do that would be wrong. At present a public company cannot be forced to distribute its profits and so has been able to accumulate large reserves upon which no taxation has been paid. Private companies have been compelled to distribute two-thirds of their profits, or in the case of holding companies, the whole of their profits. Accordingly it has been the practice and still is that (a) both companies pay on their profits; (?;) shareholders pay on their distributed dividends; and (c) in the case of a private company either dividends must be distributed or the company must pay the shareholders' tax on undistributed profits. Private companies have been at a disadvantage in every respect. "When the measure was introduced by the Treasurer (Mr. Spender) it was estimated that this tax would yield £5,300,000 per annum ; but in view of the numerous amendments which the Government proposes to introduce, can the Treasurer give us some idea of the amount which this tax is now estimated to produce? We were informed that for the year 1940-4:1 £4,250.000 would be collected. Apparently the Government is not following the legislation introduced during the last war. because we recall that it was roundly condemned by taxation commissioners, one of whom referred to it in his seventh annual report in these words -

quote.para: The tax is unequal and harsh in its incidence. These features of it are due to its peculiar construction, which, as shown by the figures quoted, permitted escape from the tax of the vast majority of large and oldestablished businesses which have made consistently substantial profits, both in amount and in percentage on capital employed, whilst small and struggling businesses, particularly those which were commenced shortly before or after the outbreak of the recent war. were obliged to pay relatively heavy amounts in tax. Many young businesses, however, find themselves in positions of technical difficulty, from which there was no relief for them under thu law. Some of those businesses had clearly benefited by the war, though it was impossible to ascertain whether their prices had been reasonable or unreasonable. Others of the youn,:;' businesses had clearly made profits, apart from war conditions, and would probably have made greater profits if the war had not occurred.

speech.para: The Government had good reasons for declining to follow closely the previous war-profits legislation. The present Minister for Information (Sir Henry

Gullett) when a private member said " It was for the rich more than for any other class that the war was fought ". He used those words in urging that the additional revenue necessary for the defence of the country should be obtained by imposing heavier taxes on the wealthy classes of the community. In my opinion, such a proposal can he amply justified, because the rich have everything to lose if we lose the war.

This bill provides that no business with a taxable profit of less than £1,000 will be liable to pay the tax proposed by the Government. The Government intends to impose certain rates upon the taxable profits of companies which exceed a certain percentage standard, namely, 8 per cent, of the capital employed by it. A special board, which will have power to increase this percentage in certain circumstances, will be set up. The rate of cax is to be graduated, commencing at 4 per cent, on the first 1 per cent, of the capital employed by which the taxable profit exceeds the percentage standard already mentioned. That is to say, if a company makes a profit of 9 per cent, on the capital employed, it will be taxed at the rate of 4 per cent, on 1 per cent, of such capital. On the second 1 per cent, profit on the capital employed by which the taxable profits exceed the percentage standard the rate will be 8 per cent., and so on. Although it is proposed that a company earning over 22 per cent, on the capital invested shall pay 60 per cent, tax, that rate does not apply to the whole amount over and above the percentage standard of 8 per cent., because the various increases are averaged; it means that the 14 per cent, profit over and above the 8 per cent., equalling 22 per cent, profit, will pay at an average rate of 30 per cent. During the last war the Government collected £7,800,000 in war-time profits tax ; this year it proposes to obtain £5,300,000 per annum. Although this latter amount is nearly as much as was received for the whole period of the last war, in view of the enormous profits which some companies have made, I wonder whether a still greater effort cannot be made by the wealthier companies.

talk.start.para: - How does the honorable member suggest that that should be done?

- I shall not discuss the details at this juncture. The Treasurer has at his disposal the services of an army of experts in the Taxation Department who, within 24 hours, could prepare a scheme to meet the situation to which I have referred. There are some wealthy companies in Australia. For instance., General Motors-Holdens Limited made a profit of over £1,000,000 in 1937, and last year its profits amounted to over £700,000. I desire to know to what degree the Government proposes to call upon that and other companies to pay taxes over and above what they were called upon to pay in peace-time. For the six years 1933-34 to 1938-39 the Government remitted taxes amounting to £5,500,000. Indirect taxes in 1919-20 amounted to £21,500,000 and during that period direct taxation yielded £20,100,000. In 1938-39 indirect taxes provided £58,700,000, whereas the proceeds from direct taxation fell to £15,200,000. In other words, while indirect taxes increased the revenue by £37,000,000, direct taxes yielded £5,000,000 less. For some years the Government has reduced direct taxation, whilst at the same time it has refused to make any provision whatsoever for better social services. To-day, with the country at war, there may be some excuse for not increasing social services, and the Government's policy in this connexion will bts accepted temporarily; but there was no justification for remitting in prewar days large amounts payable by the wealthy friends of the Government, such as big property owners, the Bank of New South "Wales, leading newspaper companies, and others. Although the Government proposes to obtain another £20,000,000 in taxes, of which £10,000,000 is to be derived from indirect taxes, I do not consider that the rich man is being called upon to sacrifice as much as the soldier, hi9 dependants and those associated with war activities will be .required to contribute. In his budget, the then British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir John Simon, pointed out that 10,000 persons in England with an income of £10,000 per annum and upwards had an aggregate income of £180,000,000. He went on to say that income tax, surtax and death duties absorbed £160,000,000 of that total. In a speech, in January last, Sir John Simon said - lae burden put on the budget by those who pay income tax and surtax may be realized when I remind you that the graduating scale rises to a figure of 17s. in the £1.

speech.para: I ask the Government to say to what degree it has followed the example of Great Britain in imposing taxes on the wealthy classes in the community.

I realize that, in order to provide adequately for the defence of Australia, heavy expenditure will be necessary this year and probably for some years to come. I do not think, however, that all of the revenue required will be obtainable from taxes. I believe that the credit resources of the nation would have to be utilized in order to provide many defence works which to-day are financed by measures imposing taxes. The Government will be forced to incur much heavier expenditure on defence than in the past. After the next election, which appears to be not far distant, a Labour government will utilize the credit resources of the nation to carry out, not only reproductive works, but also defence works which to-day are financed chiefly by taxes imposed upon the masses of the people. Such a change of financial policy can be brought about only by a change of government. I realize that I should not be in order in pursuing that subject further at this stage, and therefore I shall await the committee stage of the bill before making any further comments in relation to it.

talk.start.para: .- I find myself at some disadvantage in discussing this measure, because the Assistant Treasurer (Mr. Fadden), in explaining certain proposed amendments, has just made what might ib termed a second second-reading speech. Ever since the measure was circulated some time ago, there has been considerable controversy in relation to it. Representations have been made to me in relation to two cases of hardship in my electorate. They are typical of many others which will arise if this bill becomes law. I tried to follow the Minister's reasoning, but I was not able to determine whether his proposed amendments will afford relief in such instances. I wish to refer to the position of certain small proprietary companies which are operating in Tasmania. One was started in a small way by a man who has paid all of his profits into the business, with the result that from time to time the enterprise has been enlarged. I am informed that if this special tax be imposed and profits be taxed on the basis proposed by the Government, this industry, which deals with the scouring of sheep skins and employs a number of Australian workers, will be ruined, because it will not be able to meet its liabilities without raising additional money. This company is typical of many others that will be affected if this bill becomes law. No doubt the Assistant Treasurer and his officers are fully cognizant of the fact that in Tasmania there is special legislation covering proprietary companies. Perhaps honorable members will be told something about that when the bill is in committee. At least I hope the Assistant Treasurer will be able to satisfy the taxpayers on that point.

speech.para: I should like to deal now with the tin-mining industry. From information which I have received it appears that for a considerable time past correspondence has been passing between the Treasurer and certain taxpayers who will be affected by this legislation. I refer first to the Aberfoyle Tin Mining Company. A letter was written by it to the Treasurer on the 22nd May last, but no reply was received to the representations made. On the 2nd August, the company wrote to the Treasurer -

quote.para: We beg to remind you that a reply to our letter dated the 27th May last has not yet been received from you.

speech.para: Surely ordinary courtesy required that a reply should have been sent to the company, which had taken the trouble to set out the full particulars of its position including its capital, expenditure, profits, &c. The circumstances surrounding this case call for some explanation. The letter continued : -

quote.para: In that letter we refuted the statement made to us in your letter dated the 24th May last and also made in the press on the 1st June last that "in arriving at the taxable income a deduction is allowed to a mining company in respect of its capital expenditure on plant and development", and we informed you that in actual practice that deduction amounts to the allowance of a small portion only of such expenditure.

talk.start.para: - That has been amended.
- I know that amendments have been circulated, but honorable members are at a disadvantage because no opportunity has been given to discuss them.
- What is the name of the company to which the honorable member has referred?

- The Aberfoyle Tin Mining Company. It is a Tasmanian company, but so far the Assistant Treasurer has not favoured Tasmania with a very long visit, and I am afraid that it is now too late for him to do so because after next month the portfolio will be in different hands.

speech.para: The Assistant Treasurer has indicated by interjection that an amendment covering the matter to which I have referred is to be made, but we do not know whether or not the amendment will give the required relief. I am raising this matter now so that when the bill reaches the committee stage the Assistant Treasurer will be able to amplify his interjection and satisfy honorable members on this point at least.
I have received a letter from the Tasmanian Tin and Tungsten Producers' Association, which has its head-quarters in Launceston, in my electorate. The secretary of the association writes -

quote.para: We desire to suggest that profits arising from tin production ho exempted from the war time company tax or that some special provision be inserted in the act to meet the peculiarities of the tin mining industry.

talk.start.para: - That has been done.
- That is included in the proposed amendments?
- Yes.

- I should like to know whether or not the amendments go far enough to meet the situation in connection with which this company made representations to the Government. Here again honorable members are at a disadvantage in discussing this matter. The letter continued -

quote.para: The basis of this new taxation as set out in the bill is to be the income as assessed for Federal income tax. This assessable income is determined in the case of rnining companies before making adequate provision for amortisation of the wasting capital oyer the life of the mine. Unless full allowance is made for writing off capital expenditure which cannot be otherwise recouped, it is obvious that the assessable income will include part of the capital which has been realized during the assessable periods.

Our mines like all others are a wasting asset. In order that tin mining companies may be placed on an equitable basis with taxation, there should be some special provisions in the act to meet the different conditions. From the earnings of a tin mine there should be a sum set aside in such ;i manner that when the mine is exhausted the original investment will have been restored. It is the balance remaining after this sum is set aside which should be treated as assessable income.

speech.para: That seems to me to be a reasonable line of argument. After all, these mines are a wasting asset, and unless more generous treatment be afforded under this legislation, not only w,ill profits be taxed but also the wasting assets will cut into the capital and will not be recouped. There are some saving features in this measure. One is the setting up of a board of referees to deal with certain specific matters. I take it that the board will have power to deal with any grievances which may arise from time to time. That seems to me to be a very wise provision. In his second-reading speech the Assistant Treasurer said that a higher statutory deduction was to be allowed. I hope that the Assistant Treasurer will give the House further information on both of these matters when the bill is in committee, and will reply to the matters which I have raised in connexion with the small companies which are operating to a greater degree in Tasmania than in the mainland States. Also, I should like to hear something about how this measure will affect the mining industry, which is flourishing not only in Tasmania but in all parts of the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: - Languishing.

- I do not think that mining is languishing to any great degree in any part of Australia at present, because of the high prices of metals. The tin-mining industry suffered some setbacks for a while because of the low price of tin, but the price has now been pegged at a fairly remunerative figure and the position is very much better.

speech.para: As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Forde) said, the Opposition does not propose to oppose this measure. However, I think that some features of it will impose very great hardship on some sections of the community. The Government should have given more thorough consideration to all phases of this matter before introducing the bill. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has pointed out that indirect taxation has been levied for a number of years, and that in some cases exemption has been allowed in respect of direct taxation. There is ample scope for investigation of what use can be made of the credit resources of this country to meet the financial exigencies of the present in a way which will benefit the general community. Every care should be taken to lighten not only the burden which this generation has to carry, but also the obligations which will be handed on to future generations.

talk.start.para: .- I do not propose to deal with any of the details ot this measure. The bill is very complicated, and I am satisfied that my knowledge of taxation laws is insufficient to enable me to judge the effect of many of its provisions. It is noticeable, however, that every care is being taken in this bill to see that no injustice is done to any organization. I was rather afraid that the legislation would penalize some companies more than others. Certain organizations which have been hiding their profits for a number of years are now rushing them forward and making huge bonus share issues, which will be counted as part of the capital of the company before any tax is imposed. The honorable member for Bass (Mr. Barnard) need not worry about the effect of this taxation; the companies to which he refers are arrnply protected. Honorable members in this Parliament should realize that there is a war on and that every effort should be made to ensure that nobody will benefit to any great degree as a result of that war. Already the prices of many essential commodities have increased, and steps should be taken to ensure that such increases are not exorbitant. As an example of the contribution that the primary producers are making to our war effort, I cite the case of a small town in Western Australia which I visited recently in connexion with an appeal for war funds. There we managed to raise £2,700 free of interest, showing that the people in outback areas fully appreciate the fact that there is a war on and are prepared to make sacrifices. Unfortunately, only too often the people who are prepared to pay are allowed to do so, while others who are not so patriotic profit handsomely. During the last war, certain companies managed to evade the payment of both income tax and the special war-time profits tax, whilst other concerns, which perhaps did much less business, paid large sums in income tax and tens . of thousands of pounds in war-time profits tax. If honorable members opposite will look at the March issue of The Round Table they will find an interesting article on taxation in Germany. The article states that a single man earning 2,500 marks a year is called upon to pay a little more than 20 per cent, of that amount to the Government in taxes. A man with a wife has to pay a little less than that, while a man with a wife and children has to pay still less. All companies are taxed on profits over 6 per cent.

speech.para: The bill, as drafted, provides that no company shall pay the war-time profits tax until its profits exceed 8 per cent, after all Commonwealth and State taxes, except the war-time profits tax, have been paid. The rate of tax increases only gradually in the early stages. A company with a paid-up capital of £100,000 which made £15,000 in profits would pay £3,373 in Commonwealth and State taxes, which would leave it with £11,625. On that amount it would pay only £340 as war-time profits tax. I ask the Minister to alter the basis of the bill in order to provide that the war-time profi'ts tax shall be levied on profits exceeding 6 per cent. The increase could be small until a profit of 10 per cent, was reached. For my own part I would be in favour of the Government taking the whole of the profits in excess of 15 per cent. Certain companies have made very large profits through their war activities. That, in my opinion, is entirely wrong. All profits in excess of 15 per cent, or, it may be, even 10 per cent., after State and Commonwealth taxes have been paid, should become the property of the Government. I desire to keep costs in industry down and I am totally opposed to the making of huge profits. Before the war is over the

Commonwealth Bank, and also all the trading banks, must issue unduly large credits which may tend to increase costs, and our people will be required to pay very much heavier taxes than they do at present. We shall undoubtedly have to increase the rate of income tax. The Government is spending many millions of pounds on war equipment, and money will have to be found to pay the bills. In these times of stress certain action may have to be taken to provide money, and something in the nature of inflation may become necessary, but our bills will have to be paid by money raised through the production of wealth ultimately.

The only fair system to adopt is to oblige those who make big war-time profits to pay heavy taxes. I therefore propose to move at the committee stage of the bill that the tax shall operate in respect of all profits in excess of 6 per cent. The rate should be increased steeply after a profit of 10 per cent, is shown. We all know that many companies have increased their capital by the issue of bonus shares. The original 8s. shares of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited, for instance, were, in a very short while, declared paid up at £1. The Australian Glass Company Limited has made huge profits, and it should have been " cracked " long ago. We should not expect our people to make heavy sacrifices in their private capacity, while we allow wealthy companies to continue to make exorbitant and untaxed profits.

I shall not discuss the details of the bill, some of which, I frankly confess, are quite beyond me. I have no doubt, however, that the increased cost of living will impose a heavy burden upon the workers of this country, and that, while they are carrying this burden, they will also be expected to submit to heavier taxation. This bill should be sufficiently severe to ensure that no company will be permitted unduly to exploit the community. Exploitation has occurred. We all remember the experience of Great Britain in relation to its war-time profits taxation. In spite of the legislation in force in that country many industrial organizations made enormous profits for their shareholders. That kind of thing should not be permitted in this country.
For that reason I trust that the Government will accept amendments to this bill in order to ensure that all undue profits shall be heavily taxed.

talk.start.para: .- The Opposition is under a distinct disadvantage in discussing this bill, for the numerous amendments that have been tabled make the measure practically a new one. We are not opposed to the bill. My own opinion is that, unlike most of the measures that have been introduced by the Government, it will not result in the giving of anything to the companies that will be affected ; but neither do I think that it will take very much from them. It i3, in fact, an innocuous piece of legislation tabled for the purpose of deluding the public into the belief that something is being done to ensure more equality of sacrifice. The Labour party believes that all excess profits should be confiscated during the war. No company should be permitted to increase its rate of profit in consequence of our participation in the war. Some honorable members on the Government side of the House formerly expressed the same opinion. The fact remains, however, that certain companies have been making an enormously increased rate of profit through their war activities. Such profits should be confiscated. One of the most amazing things in connexion with the bill was the admission of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr. Fadden) to-night that as the result of certain representations made to the Government numerous amendments were to be proposed. The practice that has been adopted in this connexion is applied only to legislation affecting big business. It will be remembered that some time ago the Parliament appointed a royal commission to inquire into monetary and banking operations. After incurring considerable expense the commission made certain recommendations affecting big financial institutions in Australia. Certain legislation was then drafted to deal with the subject. The then Treasurer (Mr. Casey) subsequently held a secret conference with the representatives of these financial institutions, the decision of which he declined to divulge. One result however was that no further action was taken in respect of the amending legislation that had been prepared. No doubt influence was brought to bear upon the Government with that object.

speech.para: When this bill was first under notice a well-known chartered accountant of Sydney, Mr. Rydge, who conducts a financial journal in New South Wales, made some outspoken comments on the Government's proposals. He said that the provisions of the bill would not affect many big companies which were making enormous profits in consequence of the war. The inference from Mr. Rydge's remarks was that certain companies would be affected in some way, and that they had something to fear from the operations of the hill. A careful examination of the companies which have distributed bonus shares recently will indicate that their directors knew the best time to act and that, in fact, they had been forewarned of the Government's intentions. Some companies were not forewarned, and it is, no doubt, from these that the proposed amendments have come. I predict that the Commonwealth Treasury will not receive very much revenue from the operations of this measure.

I wish to examine some of the remarks made by the Assistant Treasurer to-night concerning the meaning of the amendments that are to be moved. The honorable gentleman read very rapidly the speech that had been carefully prepared for him by his departmental officers, and it was therefore difficult to follow his reasoning. I was able however to scribble some notes while he was speaking. I understood him to say that exemptions might be granted in the case of companies which undertook a greater element of risk than other companies. He said that a board of referees would be appointed to decide what constituted " greater risk " but he did not say who would constitute the board of referees. Judging from the appointments that this Government has made to boards of one kind or another in recent months, J shall not be surprised to see appointed to the board of referees the directors of certain wealthy companies which will be expected to pay this tax. We may be very sure that persons directly interested will be put in the position to regulate the imposition of the tax. The

Assistant Treasurer did not mention the kinds of businesses which in his opinion incurred greater elements of risk. I should like to know what kind of businesses he has in mind. Apparently the averaging system of taxation which was discarded a year or two ago, is to be revived.

talk.start.para: - That is not right.

- I understood the Assistant Minister to say that if a company made large profits in one year it would be entitled to offset them against the lower profits made in previous years. Under that system we may be quite sure that the companies will be able to show that they are not earning sufficient profits to become liable to this taxation.
- I take it that that statement referred to pastoral companies which might have a good year following upon two or three bad years.

- The Assistant Treasurer did not say anything about pastoral companies. Perhaps he will tell us whether he had them in mind. It is well known that big pastoralists very often have interests in other than pastoral activities. They may reap a large profit from those interests and only a smaller profit from their pastoral activities. Apparently the Government proposes to permit them to offset their smaller profits against their larger profits without reviewing, in any way, their ability to pay. That factor should undoubtedly be taken into consideration. Although a worker, who has only his labour to sell, may be unemployed and receive no income in any particular year, he is not permitted to offset his lack of income in that year against his income in a subsequent year when he may earn just sufficient to become liable for the payment of tax. This Government, or this Parliament, has never suggested that a concession of this kind should be applied in such cases. Unless it takes into consideration the circumstances of each taxpayer, as it does the circumstances of each industry, it is useless for the Government to talk about equality of sacrifice. The board of referees is to compute the capital employed in any company, and that body will not be governed by the limitations set out in the original bill. Incidentally, the

speech.para: Minister has not indicated who the referees will be. In view of past experience I imagine that these referees will discover many ingenious methods whereby the larger companies will be enabled to escape a considerable amount, if not the whole, of the tax. I understood the Minister to say that dividends from subsidiary companies could not be taken into account in computing the tax. What constitutes subsidiary companies? The definition in the bill is not convincing. For example, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited has a number of subsidiary companies which are engaged in many activities. I feel certain that that company will be able to regulate its profits by increasing costs of production in its various subsidiary companies. By this and other methods it will be able to evade considerable tax under this legislation. Many other companies fall within the same category. How often have we been told that the Colonial Sugar Refining Company Limited does not make any appreciable profit out of its operations in Australia; that the bulk of its profits is made in Fiji and other countries. That argument has been put forward by certain honorable members on many occasions. In view of cases of this kind, how can we provide adequately for the determination of the amount of capital involved in the production of profits in our larger companies ? The Minister also said that it was desired to allow reasonable dividends to companies. The honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory) said that he would confiscate all dividends over 15 per cent. The average man would be happy if he had profitable investments and would readily agree to the Government confiscating all dividends over 15 per cent., The Labour party believes that it would be reasonable to confiscate war-time profits entirely. What does the Government propose to do with regard to watered stock? The Minister said that, in computing the capital upon which the rate of dividend was to be determined it was reasonable to include cash reserves, or reserves built up out of profits of other years, because, he contended, those reserves belonged to the shareholders, and as they were provided for the purpose of solidifying the position of the company, were employed to some degree in the production of profits. However, the Minister knows that reserves are built up for the purpose not only of solidifying the position of a company but also of hiding the company's true financial position. A method commonly employed is to build up large reserves, and, when the time is opportune, to increase capital through a distribution of bonus shares. In most cases the money devoted to the extension of plant and operations for the purpose of increasing profits is not new capita], but money accumulated in reserve through exploitation of the public. If we were able to get down to bedrock we should find that many companies which now possess large capital started with very little and built it up as the result of their power to exploit the public over a number of years. Unless the Government is prepared to take cognizance of facts of this kind, it will not be able to provide for what it terms reasonable dividends, but, on the contrary, will only enable these companies to continue to exploit the general public and to evade making their just contribution towards the cost of carrying on the war.

I agree with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Forde) that people who have invested money in profitable undertakings have much more at stake in this war than have workers who have enlisted in the Army, Navy and Air Force. In order to enlist numbers of our soldiers have relinquished good jobs, carrying comfortable salaries, and have been prepared to accept miserable pay for military service because they believe that their duty is to make some contribution towards the defence of their country. On the other hand, however, the Government not only intends to relieve the large corporations from any risks in regard to their investments, but also is determined to protect them in every possible way. For instance, as the result of Government war expenditure, these companies are being provided with greater opportunities to increase their profits.

I repeat that this measure does not meet with my full approval. As I have already said, whilst this bill will take very little from these companies, at the same time it will not give anything to them. However, if we on this side of the chamber were to oppose the measure, the Government would say that we were opposing its proposals to tax the larger companies. No doubt after the election we shall be occupying the Government benches. In the interim we urge the Government to oblige the larger companies to make a fair contribution towards the cost of our war effort. In introducing this measure, the Government simply seeks to place itself in the position of being able to say to the electors that, whilst it has asked the average citizen to contribute towards our war effort, it has asked the big companies also to make their fair share of sacrifice. This bill is merely electioneering propaganda and window dressing. If the Government were sincere in its expressed desire to prevent the big companies from making increased profits in war-time, it would confiscate all war profits. On the contrary, however, it proposes to appoint a board of referees which will be able to devise ways and means to enable the big companies to evade this tax.

talk.start.para: .- The Opposition, I assume, approves of this measure for political reasons, but, at the same time, reserves the right to criticize it. The Minister estimates that this tax will yield £5,000,000 annually. In view of that fact, this measure cannot be described as a mere electioneering gesture. We must remember that the tax has been designed solely as a tax on war profits over a certain limit, and that profits to be made in this war are not likely to be so great as was the case during the last war. It is to the Government's credit that early in the war it took steps to keep down the cost of commodities. That necessarily limits profits. In view of this fact I was agreeably surprised to hear the Minister say that he anticipated that this tax would yield £5,000,000 annually. Indeed, when this bill was before the House last session I entertained a great deal of doubt as to whether it would meet the situation satisfactorily. Certainly, it represents an improvement upon legislation of a similar character passed during the last war, when the more powerful companies were allowed to escape their fair share of tax, whilst, at the same time, injustice was inflicted upon many concerns, especially those which had just commenced operations, or made accidental profits during the war. It would appear, at first glance, that many of the most powerful financial institutions in this country are likely to escape payment of this tax altogether, and I am still of opinion that some ground exists for that view. I formed that opinion after I had had the benefit of a conversation with the honorable member for Lilley (Mr. Jolly), than whom, perhaps, there is no better authority in this House on the subject of company taxation. It appears to be very doubtful whether many of the oldestablished and more powerful financial institutions will pay any appreciable tax under this measure, because those institutions have been pursuing a conservative course over the years, seldom paying more than 8 per cent, dividend, but, at the same time, establishing reserves and increasing their capital by the issue of bonus shares.
- That aspect is covered by this measure.

- To some degree that is so ; indeed one reason why I shall support the bill is because it provides for the checking up of capital used in the business. On the other hand, this is a tax on war profits over a certain limit, and we must fix some limit, whether it be 8 per cent, or any other figure. The logical way to fix such a standard is on the basis of profits earned. It would not be logical to fix it on capital, or on the extent of a company's operations. Dividends of S per cent., or over, will be liable to this tax. It is proposed also to appoint a board of referees to determine the capital upon which the rate of dividend shall be based. I hope that these referees will examine very astutely the balance-sheets of the larger companies. There is a very strong suspicion that the most successful companies employ the best accountants and lawyers and that to a great degree they succeed in concealing their assets. They also proceed on the conservative basis, perhaps on the whole a wise basis, of not distributing too much of their profits but of holding a safe margin by way of capital. One purpose for which they have done that is that they have not desired to appear too affluent in the statements which they present to the public. I believe there is some ground for the suspicion which exists that there is need for a very close examination of the balance sheets and the books of the larger corporations extending back over a number of years.
- The expert officers of the Taxation Department have conducted such investigations for a number of years. Their tax reports are based on these investigations.

- I know that the Taxation Department has been very efficient, but taxation is an ever increasing business, and it is no small task for the comparatively small number of expert examiners in the Taxation Department to go into the past transactions of hig corporations. I have a good deal of confidence in the officers of the department, and I hope that when a year has expired and we know the result of this taxation, the Treasurer will be able to inform us, without giving names, that this legislation has been attached to the big financial companies such as the Colonial Sugar Refining Company Limited, whose profits amount to approximately £1,000,000 a year.
- Profits made in Australia ?

- There is a good deal of suspicion in my mind as to the value of the claim made by the Colonial Sugar Refining Company Limited that its profits are earned outside Australia. That subject has been discussed in some detail in this House, and I believe that there is a great deal of doubt as to whether the company could uphold its claim that its profits are really made outside Australia. The original draft of this bill has been improved very substantially by the amendments which have been incorporated in it. In reply to the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) I would say that those amendments have been dictated not by big business, but on the contrary have been inserted for the purpose of giving relief to smaller business men. Undoubtedly this bill will hit proprietary companies, not the largest, and perhaps not the smallest, but mostly private companies. Many of them, of course, are making large profits. Where any company is making a profit of 8 per cent, or more, there is no reasonable ground for saying that it should not pay some extra taxes during the war period.

speech.para: I wish now to deal with the position of private companies consisting of one or two persons, or of a few persons, whose capital is small, but whose real assets consist of the personal capacity of the working members rather than the amount of subscribed capital. Some of those conducting these companies are making good incomes on a very small nominal capital, but they should not be taxed unnecessarily or unfairly on what would otherwise be nominally income from personal exertion.

talk.start.para: - Such companies are provided for in the bill.
- I am relying on the Assistant Treasurer (Mr. Fadden) to give a better explanation of that provision than I am able to obtain.

.- There is not a great deal left to be said on this bill. What I propose to say can be said in a very few words. The bill represents a substantial improvement on the War-time Profits Tax Act passed during the 1914-18 war. This bill as proposed to be amended by the Government represents a very great improvement upon the form in which it was originally drafted, and to a considerable degree will remove certain anomalies and inequalities which were found in the original measure. It is apparent thatvery considerable care has been taken by the Treasurer and the officers of his department to arrive at a just basis for the computation of working capital. That is a most important matter when one is attempting to decide the rate of interest which shall escape taxation and that which shall be called upon to bear it. Contrasting the legislation passed during the 1914-18 war with this bill, if my memory serves me rightly, the act passed to take toll of war-time profits in the Great War dealt with excess profits only rather than excessive profits. There is a distinction, I think, between the two terms. In the act dealing with excess profits made during the Great War, the factor which decided whether a company should be taxed was whether or not the company had made profits in excess of what it had been making prior to the war. So, under that act a company might have been making huge profits before the Great War, but unless it made a still higher profit during the war, it would escape liability for tax under that measure. On the other hand, a company making relatively small profits prior to the Great War, whose profits during the war period went up to some degree, would be taxed on whatever that excess might be. This bill, in my opinion, contains a very great improvement on that principle because it imposes tax on excessive profits rather than excess profits. The distinction which I am trying to draw between the use of the words " excessive " and " excess " is simply that profits under this bill do not require to be in excess of what a company was making before the present war. So long as profits are excessive from the point of view of what they should be in war-time they are taxable. In the bill now before us a common figure of 8 per cent, is laid down above which taxation shall commence for all companies. The tax rises by steps of 4 per cent, to a maximum limit of 60 per cent., which limit is reached when a company is making profits that would represent interest of 23 per cent, on capital. The attempt to make this a graded tax is in strict accord with what we do in connexion with personal income tax. We make the man who has a big income pay at a much higher rate than the man whose income is small - that is reasonable - and in this bill we propose to tax much more heavily companies making high rates of interest on their capital than those whose rate of interest on their capital is less. If this bill were as unalterable as the laws of the Medes and Persians, I would be opposed to it, because it does not go as far as I feel sure will later become necessary. I would not be satisfied to leave as a permanency any war-time tax which loaves companies with about 80 per cent, of the profits that they make up to 23 per cent, on their capital, and with 40 per cent, of anything they make in excess of that 23 per cent. That is how it works out. Honorable members will realize that the first 8 per cent, is not taxable, and that on the next 15 per cent, the gradations of tax rise until the cm full 60 per cent, is reached at the top figure, so that half of the 60 per cent, is really the average that is taken from the difference between 8 per cent, and 23 per cent. About 30 per cent, is taken of the profits in excess of 8 per cent, and up to 23 per cent., and if one spreads that 30 per cent, over the whole of the 23 per cent., really about one-fifth or 20 per cent., is taken in taxation from the company, which is left with SO per cent, of the first 23 per cent, dividend that it makes. In excess of that, it is left with 40 per cent., because 60 per cent, is the maximum percentage of taxation imposed. Whilst I look upon that as insufficient, I do not think that it will be permanent, and I think it wiser to put the taxation screw on gradually rather than do it with a full twist, because if it is done gradually, there will be less risk of a heavy slump of values of shares and of reduction of employment through companies curtailing their activities owing to excessive taxation. I think, though, if the war lasts, it will be necessary to make increasingly heavy levies upon profits, and I believe that this bill will leave room to do so in three ways. The time may come when it will ba necessary, if this war lasts for any considerable time, to lower the standard of 8 per cent. That is one way in which this taxation can be increased. Another way is by increasing the height of the gradations, making them, for instance, 5 or 6 per cent, instead of 4 per cent., and the third way is by carrying the gradations up to a greater final height, perhaps up to 80 per cent, or even to 100 per cent, over and above a certain profit level. That may have to be done in the future, but I am content with the bill as it is for the present because of the wisdom of tightening the taxation screw gradually.

- The total yield from this tax in one year will be approximately £5,000,000. That does not appear to be a substantial contribution to be made in war-time by all companies whose dividends exceed 8 per cent.
- That is so, but £5,000,000 is not the total of the taxes which companies will pay. They will be called upon to pay the ordinary company rate of tax.
- Quite so, but that point appeared to me to be relevant to the honorable member's argument about the obligation to tax excessive profits regardless of how they are earned.

- I see the honorable gentleman's point. Reference has been made to-night to large and powerful companies, and they have been contrasted with smaller companies. It has been suggested that some of them may, or, indeed, will, escape this particular tax, whilst small companies with much less capital will be taxed. Well, the basis of taxation in this bill is dependent on not the size of the company, but the rate of profit which the company is making in relation to its capital. One might have a large and powerful company making a profit of 5 per cent, on its capital and a small company making 50 per cent. The small company would he taxed because it was making an exceedingly high rate of profit on its capital, and the large would escape because thi rate of profit which it was earning on its capital investment was relatively small. Then, again, large and powerful companies very often consist of a large number of small shareholders, whereas often the shareholders in small companies are a few wealthy men. Some of the sympathy given to the smaller companies in that respect is perhaps wasted.
- Mo3t of the capital of big companies consists of watered stock.
- I think that the Treasury is taking care of the position regarding what can be accepted as working capital.
- It needs to do so.
- Yes. Great credit is due to the Treasury officials who have put that matter on a proper basis and excluded, for example, goodwill unless it is paid for in hard cash.
- Otherwise, it is an endowment provided by the community.
- Exactly. I support the bill, but I do not regard the rates as final. They are the start, but I believe that they will have to be raised.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
