talk.start.para: .- I bring under the notice of the Government what I consider to be a very serious infringement of the rights of the Labour party in this country. The Labour party at the moment in New South Wales is engaged in a by-election campaign in the Tamworth State electorate, and we find that it has been seriously handicapped by the censorship authorities, which, we consider, were actuated by nothing more than political motives. The purpose was to hinder the Labour party's campaign. The Labour party had proposed to make recordings of speeches by prominent- members of the movement and broadcast them throughout the electorate. The script of these speeches was handed to the censorship authorities, who took no exception to it. Doubtless they read it and disagreed with the subject-matter; but they were not prepared to say that that was why they took action to ban the broadcasting of these speeches. They said that the script was all right, but they objected to artificial sounds which were introduced into the recordings at different periods to denote applause and interjections. In order that honorable members may understand the position I shall read one or two extracts from one of the banned speeches. No doubt members of the Country party and the United Australia party will then understand why the censorship authorities, because of their political bias, used their power to prevent these recordings from being broadcast to the people. The script read -

quote.para: It lias been loosely and falsely stated by United Australia party propagandists that Labour has no practical policy for successful prosecution of the war against Fascism. 1 now want to give that imputation the lie direct. Let us first of all take a glance at current history. France has surrendered. The terms imposed on our former ally by Hitler and Mussolini mean the complete domination of France by the Fascists. How was this surrender brought about? This point is important. It was not brought about by the mass of the people who loved their country. France surrendered as a result of intrigue on the part of wealthy bankers, big business men and monopolists - men who would rather sacrifice their country than their business and their profits. Very well.

To-day, Australia faces the crisis - a crisis brought about, not by the Australian people, who also love their country, but by the Government, which in the past supported Chamberlain's policy of appeasement. Let me remind you, my friends, that to-day Chamberlain and Daladier have been condemned by the very people who supported them. We are called upon - and rightly so - to be anti-Fascists in every thought and deed.

talk.start.para: - Mr. Speaker, I rise to a point of order. The honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) is not reading the script correctly. It contains more than he has indicated. Artificial applause is inserted in the script.

speech.para: There is no point of order, but I remind the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) that he must accept responsibility for what he says when he makes a quotation in this House.

talk.start.para: - I accept full responsibility, Mr. Speaker.

speech.para: The script continued -

quote.para: But let me ask you, " Who are Fascist in this country?" Let me tell you, "The Labour movement - the workers - are anti-Fascist, the defenders of freedom, security and democracy." Cast your mind back a little while. Who was it demanded the deportation of the Nazi spy, Von Luckner? 'J.he Labour movement. Who was it that entertained and feted the Nazi count? Prominent members of the United Australia party!

speech.para: Cries of " Shame " are inserted at this stage -

quote.para: Let mc remind you of something else. It was the Labour Government that demanded, "No war materials for confessed enemies of Australia". It was the United Australia party-United Country party Government which coerced the waterside workers into loading scrap iron for consignment to an Axis power. Make no mistake, Labour is the strongest bulwark of all against Fascist oppression. The Australian Labour movement will fight to the death against Hitlerism and Fascism in all its forms. But Labour does not agree that the way to defeat Fascism is by Fascism.

speech.para: This is the kind of speech that I should like to make in the Tamworth by-election campaign, because it coincides with my views and those of the Labour party generally. The remainder of the script is very interesting. On some other occasion I shall probably read it to this House. I have read these brief extracts in order to indicate to honorable members what kind of a speech had been banned by the censorship authorities.

Immediately I learned that exception had been taken to these recordings I attempted to communicate with the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies), who was then in Brisbane, but I was unable to get in touch with him. I spoke to his private secretary, who advised me to communicate with Sir Keith Murdoch, who is in charge of the Department of Information. I then telephoned Sir Keith Murdoch in Melbourne and he said that, although he had discussed the matter with the Chief Censor, Mr. Jenkins, he himself was not responsible for the decision of the authorities ; it was a matter entirely for Mr. Jenkins. I next spoke to the Chief Censor, who said that the authorities had taken exception to the recordings because they regarded them as " fakes ". They considered that, as the speech had not been delivered at a meeting, the recording conveyed a wrong impression. Anybody who knows anything about radio broadcasting will agree with me that 60 per cent, of radio programmes on all matters are what might be called " fakes " in the sense that various sounds are introduced in order to create certain impressions in the minds of listeners. The fact that applause is indicated at periods in the speech is not misleading, because if that speech were delivered to an intelligent audience anywhere it would be applauded to a greater degree than the sound effects in the recording actually suggest. I submit that the whole of the script is an accurate record of how Labour supporters and, in fact, any democrats in this country, would express their opinions of the present Government.

The most serious aspect of this matter is that the censorship organization was established not for the purpose of exercising political bias but for the purpose of preventing the dissemination of news or views likely to be prejudicial to national defence. It is a ridiculous state of affairs if the censorship authorities, who are not answerable to the people, can set themselves up as judges, not only of what might be considered to be valuable information for the enemy, but also of what is permissible for political organizations to place before the general public.
The practice of making recordings to be broadcast during political campaigns is not new. The United Australia party and the United Country party have used similar propaganda.

talk.start.para: - Their records were usually truthful.

- In previous political campaigns the United Australia party and the United Country party have sent their sound trucks travelling round country districts in order to broadcast such recordings. In those recordings applause has been indicated at appropriate places and no exception has been taken to them by the authorities. It is .remarkable that on this occasion, the first upon which any exception has been taken to this procedure, the action was taken against the Labour party during the course of the Tamworth byelection campaign. I bring this matter before Parliament now so as to indicate to honorable members, and to the public, the manner in which the Government, through, its officials, is allowing power to be abused. This action indicates the handicap which is likely to be placed upon the Labour party in the forthcoming elections. We have been told that public servants should have no political opinions in the conduct of their departments - that they should have no "political bias on the job. That, we have been assured, is the principle that has always guided the Public Service. Now, it would appear, the Government is selecting, as officials, particularly for the Censorship Branch, officers whose political opinions it approves, knowing that those officials can be relied upon to prevent the Labour party from presenting its case properly and fairly to the public. I ask honorable members what is the really important part of any speech. It is not the applause or the cheers or the cries of " Shame ", but the matter contained in the speech, whether that matter be conveyed over the radio, or by the printed word, or personally by a candidate addressing an audience. The action of the Censorship Office is an infringement of our rights. Mr. Rorke, of the Sydney censorship Office, was asked whether he would permit the records to be broadcast if they were made at a meeting convened by the

speech.para: Labour party, and addressed by Labour speakers, and, to our surprise, he said that there would be no objection to that procedure. Yet the records of which I nave spoken were banned because it was alleged they were fakes. As to that, I need only point out that instalments of a play are broadcast over the national network every Sunday night, and in the theatre where the broadcast is made a man with a large cardboard placard on which is printed the word " Applause " comes to the front of the stage every time that the producer of the play wants the audience to applaud. It is obvious, therefore, that the objection of the censorship official to the broadcast of the Labour party's records was based on a mere pretext. Apart from that, I maintain that it is not the function of the censorship officials to say whether such things are a fake or not. Their job is to prevent valuable information from reaching the enemy. In this instance, the officials have exceeded their authority. If the defence of the Government is that this action was taken on the responsibility of the Censorship Office, then the Government can prove its good faith by immediately giving instructions that this stupid proceeding must cease.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member has exhausted his time.
